Cinematographer: Alex Hill 

Alexander Hill is a Cinematographer based in New York. Born in Germany to a family in the armed services, he was able to see many parts of the world early in his life.  This is where he discovered his love of story telling.  His works allows him to blend this interest along with both art and technology.  Alex focuses on narrative and commercial work, often specializing in beauty and fashion pieces.  He has shot campaigns for L'Oréal, S'well Bottle, eBay, Stella Artois, Adore Me, and several fashion brands.  He has also recently collaborated with George Pelecanos, independent film producer and former writer for The Wire, on his most recent short film, Confidential Informant, adapted from the short story.  Alex first worked with Jonathan Chekroune on his short film Sasha.  - http://alexanderhill.tv/​ 
 
Writer: Matt Stall

Matt Stall studied Creative Writing and Film History at Miami University, Oxford, OH as well as Screen Writing and Film Production at Full Sail University, Winter Park, FL on his way to two degrees.  He has written or co-written several short films and ghost writes material for a popular YouTube personality.  CECILE is Matt's first collaboration with Jonathan Checkroune.
 
Editor: Ryan Devine

Ryan Devine is an editor at Giaronomo Productions, a movie trailer house in New York City. He's worked on marketing campaigns for major motion pictures such as Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, Arrival and Kingsman: The Secret Service, among many others. He grew up in Centerville, Ohio and studied video production at Ohio University. 
 https://vimeo.com/ryandevine
 
Composer: Ben Devine

Ben Devine is a sound mixer and composer. He first collaborated with Jonathan Chekroune on "Sasha" which won him Best Score Award at the 2016 NYC Indie Film Festival. 
https://soundcloud.com/bendevine7

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • My name is Lachlan McCarron and I am the Producer of Christmas Lunch
  • I have been working on Producing this film for a number of months now and am very excited to see the story made and brought to the screen.
  • Any donations you can provide will go towards production funding in essential departments.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are looking to raise around $2000 for this production. We have other fundraising events planned and hope that this page can add to the small kitty we already have.
  • By donating you will have the chance to win perks such as film credits and take home props from the actual set!
  • Absolutely ALL revenue made from this page will be put towards the production, whether we make our goal or not.

The Impact

  • This project is important to me because it is a story that explores the truth of what it means to be family, both the good and the ugly side of it.
  • Between our talented crew there are a number of projects that we have worked on, however this will easily be one of our biggest challenges yet.
  • For you, it is the choice to donate a few dollars or not. For us, this is our graduate film, but more so it is our first attempt to create something truly special that we can be proud of and push to gain recognition in our field of work. For us, its everything we have been working for.

Risks & Challenges

  • Having Produced short film pieces before, I have experience with taking on such challenges but am always keen to learn from new experiences.
  • There is always a solution to every problem. The unfortunate thing is, most of those solutions cost money. Any donations that you can offer will be put to good use in order to solve problems and create high quality content.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't help with donations, any noise you can make about our campaign will always help attract other potential donors, so please Share Share Share!!
  • Be sure to make use of the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

My name is Lachlan McCarron and I am the Producer of Christmas Lunch
I have been working on Producing this film for a number of months now and am very excited to see the story made and brought to the screen.
Any donations you can provide will go towards production funding in essential departments.


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise around $2000 for this production. We have other fundraising events planned and hope that this page can add to the small kitty we already have.
By donating you will have the chance to win perks such as film credits and take home props from the actual set!
Absolutely ALL revenue made from this page will be put towards the production, whether we make our goal or not.


The Impact

This project is important to me because it is a story that explores the truth of what it means to be family, both the good and the ugly side of it.
Between our talented crew there are a number of projects that we have worked on, however this will easily be one of our biggest challenges yet.
For you, it is the choice to donate a few dollars or not. For us, this is our graduate film, but more so it is our first attempt to create something truly special that we can be proud of and push to gain recognition in our field of work. For us, its everything we have been working for.


Risks & Challenges

Having Produced short film pieces before, I have experience with taking on such challenges but am always keen to learn from new experiences.
There is always a solution to every problem. The unfortunate thing is, most of those solutions cost money. Any donations that you can offer will be put to good use in order to solve problems and create high quality content.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help with donations, any noise you can make about our campaign will always help attract other potential donors, so please Share Share Share!!
Be sure to make use of the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Now more than ever the world needs you to stand up and be counted.

We need YOUR donations to help us get this important film through the post production stage.

No one could have predicted the impact of the Women’s March. What began as a small, personal crusade soon became a global movement.

A march for all of us – regardless of gender, class, or ethnicity – a march governments could not ignore.

One year on, ‘We Still Rise’ documents how it all began, interviewing the leaders who mobilised the movement almost overnight, people from every walk of life who took to the streets, and the big names who helped spread the word.

We are tantalisingly close to recognising those who made everything possible, despite often risking their personal safety.

To date this project has been self funded and made through the hard work and good will of both our crew and many Women's March supporters from around the globe. In short, we need your help.

We are now going into our edit phase and will need to raise additional funds to get us across the line. 

We have a target of £70,000 to ensure we can use the best archive footage, add animation, license music and ensure that we can deliver the best version of this documentary that the movement so rightly deserves .

We can even start to pay back some of the good will that we have received. 10% of everything we raise through our fundraising will go back to the Women's March organisations.

So every donation beyond our target, large or small, is important to us and greatly appreciated. 

You would be supporting a documentary that captures a pivotal moment in our collective history. That safeguards a vital message for future generations.

You would be marching too.

 

The Ultimate Prize

Illma Gore, the world-famous artist, has lent her support to this project and has donated an original piece to be auctioned off. This has been set at a reserve price of £10,000 by the artist herself. Considering that one of her recent artworks is listed at London’s Maddox Gallery for £1 million, the reserve price is a bargain. This piece is currently in production and as soon as it is complete, we'll list it for bidding.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t afford to contribute financially it doesn't mean you can't help.  Consider doing one if not all of the below...

1. Send this Indiegogo link to your friends and colleagues.
2. Like and follow our Facebook page here.
3. Sign up for our mailing list on our website and receive periodic updates.
4. Follow us on Twitter & Instagram — retweet, repost and share, share, share! 
5. Talk about the project to everyone you know. 

We are all in this together so whatever you can do to help would be gratefully received and acknowledged. Together we can make sure the world continues to hear the voices of the 5 million women who began the movement.

 

The Team

Dagmara Kodlubanski – Producer, Director

Australian-raised, Dagmara runs her own live action and animation production company in London. With a background in journalism and broadcast radio in Australia, she had her own radio show in Melbourne, and has produced and presented shows on a variety of subject matters, from popular culture to 9/11. She also has experience working in a number of technology startups, including the Skype founders. This project has been the perfect way for her to combine her background in journalism, and her passion for content production.

 

Andy Malone – Producer

Andy has a wide range of programming experience –from documentary to factual television in the UK, Ireland, China, the USA and Japan. He has developed and produced major projects for VICE, Channel 4, Channel 5, BBC, Olympic Channel and RTE. Andy was part of the team that won the 2014 Irish Film & Television Award for Best Reality Series with ‘Operation Transformation’.

 

Mallory Khalifa – Producer

Mallory, an entrepreneur, has over ten years experience in live action and animation production, overseeing large scale budgets, business development and vendor negotiations. As Managing Director of a production company in London, she is responsible for the Europe, Middle-East, Africa and Asia markets. She has worked on high profile campaigns for agencies such as Saatchi & Saatchi, Adam&EveDDB, BBDO, Leo Burnett, Ogilvy & Mather, Grey, and brands; MARS, Unilever, Coca-Cola, Reckitt Benckiser, P&G, and Pepisco, and has been instrumental in their delivery.

 

Justin Batchelor - Director of Photography

Justin works as a Director, D.O.P. with a strong focus in narrative storytelling. A passion for writing and creating a language for visual translation has led to the creation of numerous short films and documentaries.

story:
Oliver Rogers is the spark that lit this fire cracker of a project. After studying TV & Film production at college, and gaining the highest possible marks at BTEC level 3, Oliver decided that university wasn't for him; he wanted to make films, not write about them. Since then he has been working on a variety of projects, both his own and other's to build his experience, and in this way has made many contacts who are joining him on this project. 

 

Director Statement

This story is a fictional narrative, but was inspired by real interviews with whistle blowers. This is a controversial subject and even on the crew we have a range of  sceptics, believers and undecided. Whether you believe this story is showing the truth that there is more going on in our solar system than we imagine, or is a work of science fiction, I hope that you will enjoy our film, and that it will inspire you to want to know more about the subject.

The cast and crew will be working voluntarily (including, we hope, a celeb or two). However we want this to look as good as the script and acting are, so we need to hire professional kit. Production values will also be important with respect to set, location and prop hire. Lastly we have to get to the locations, and feed the army of techs, grunts and actors (grunts is an affectionate term for infantry men, but in our case, our producers!) We're making the film anyway, but your investment will help make it look and sound the best it can.

By investing in our exciting feature film you will help to bring these topics to a wider audience and generate discussion around what are for many new and challenging ideas. You can also be part of creating an entertaining film which, we hope, you will be proud to be associated with.We have a growing group of followers, which includes a band! 'Creatures of Habit' are on board and will be providing the soundtrack/theme music. 

Hey and you also get perks!

They are listed in the usual place but include, original art work,  security card USB drive with an MP4 of the final film, two packages to visit the set and Exec Producer credits.

Where will you be able to see the film?

For those who don’t choose the USB or Premier investment options, first we'll do the festival circuit, then we hope it will be shown on a digital download channel or maybe even in your local cinema.

So what are the Benefits & Risks, well we hope the benefits are explained above, the risks are small:

Alien invasion

A visit from the men in black

You don't like the film!

That's it! 

If you can't help financially, then please help by sharing this with friends.

Thank you and we look forward to sharing this exciting project with you all.

story:
Resumen

Esta es la historia de Carmen, una apasionada doctora que junto a sus compañeros tratará de salvar la vida del ¨Niño C¨, un pequeño que llega al Hospital Nacional de Niños en un terrible estado. Esta es la historia de muchos niños en Costa Rica, y no solo aquí, sino en todo Latinoamérica.

Queremos hacer la primera película costarricense sobre el maltrato infantil.

Soy Javier Sosa, y escribí este guion basado en hechos reales para alzar la voz sobre este flagelo de la sociedad y sobre como nosotros podemos hacer conciencia para cambiarlo.

Mi equipo y yo queremos honrar a estos niños, a los que no tienen voz, a los que no se pueden defender del maltrato que  muchas veces viene de quienes, se supone, deberían cuidarlos.

Únase a nosotros, hagamos comunidad: Ya tenemos el equipo técnico necesario y algunos aportes, pero nos faltan $40.000 para gastos de producción,  pago de actores y equipo así como alimentación. $1, $5, su aporte ¡Si hará la diferencia!

Riesgos y desafíos

De no alcanzar la meta corremos el riesgo de no tener los fondos suficientes para poder cumplir con toda la  filmación. Aun así, vamos para adelante confiados de que usted ya ha decidido ayudarnos.

Ayúdenos también difundiendo esta campaña y así apoyarnos a llegar a nuestra meta.

This story is about Carmen, a passionate doctor that will try to save The Kid C life, A child who enters the ER of the National Children Hospital in a terrible shape.

This is the story of many children in Costa Rica, and not only here but in whole Latin America.

I am Javier Sosa and I wrote this script base in a real case to raise a voice against this problematic in our society and how we can encourage awareness to change this situation.

My crew and I, we want to honor this kids, the ones without a voice, the ones who can´t defeat themselves againts  the abuse that many times came from the ones who are supossed to take care of them.

Join us, let´s make comunity: We already have the technical equipment but we need $40000 for production and to pay the actor and the crew. $1, $5, your support. ¡Will make the difference!

story:
Halloween. Pumpkins. Who cares?

I know I didn’t until a weird question popped into my head:

What happens to pumpkins after Halloween?

The story quickly unfolded about a pumpkin living on the streets with a homeless man and it’s stuck with me for years. I would tell the story at dinner parties, around family at Christmas and even on a date once (my attempt at small talk). Seeing the genuine surprise and delight of people around me, reacting to his dark but sweet story, I decided to direct the film myself.

Last year, I wrote and co-directed The Green Light District, a short film about the optimistic outlook of real sex workers in Bristol. Seeing the BBC news coverage it was given, has made me hungry to make films that people will remember. Even on their deathbed.

For this project, I’m lucky enough to be joined by a team of film-making superheroes, including EasterEnders actor Tom Holloway, Americana musician Danni Nicholls and the husband and wife production team of Denis & Timea Moldovan. They’ve been with me on this project for over a year and have been amazing every step of the way as we develop this little epic.

 

The Treatment

I'm all for saving pumpkins

after all this is what princesses use to make into carriages

These are the words of Tom Holloway's friend, Irina, after hearing about the film, which I thought was kind of beautiful. The Last Jack O’Lantern is a dark fairytale for modern times. Homelessness has replaced the dragon. The man living on the street, Adam, is a potential knight in shining armour and the beautiful princess is a plump pumpkin who survived Halloween.

And the focus and the way I will shoot the film is all about pumpkins. A world from their perspective. Instead of pumpkins being decorative, it will be people who will play that role in the film’s scenes.

You will see Christmas shoppers passing by Jack, the hero pumpkin and the homeless guy Adam. as well as revellers at Halloween parties in the ‘pumpkin rave' scene. But, in both scenes you will never see their faces. Other than the homeless man, people are on the edge of frame; they’re on periphery. For once, we enter in to a pumpkin’s world.

It’s a cat and mouse world in Tom and Jerry.  The human face is never visible.

Our pumpkin hero Jack does not move on its own accord. It does not talk.  After all, ‘he’ is just a vegetable.

But, the way Adam cares for him. The way we shoot from the pumpkin’s perspective. And through music too. He comes alive.

I’m interested in the way people can feel for inanimate objects, especially through the magic of film. It’s worth checking out Spike Jonze’s ‘Lamp’. It’s a junk of metal, but you are heartless, if you don’t feel like rushing into the streets to give the lamp a home by the end of the advert.

Throughout the Last Jack O'Lantern, we toy with the audience with the idea of magic realism. Is Jack actually alive?

The opening shot is our hero pumpkin with a winter hat on and a spare change cup in front of him. People ignore him, until eventually someone kindly drops him a few pennies. At this point, the homeless man’s hand comes in to frame to raise the cup in acknowledgment. We are back in a very real world. Is the pumpkin just a prop for the homeless man to get more money?

Later in the film, we go back in time to the day after Halloween- a scene we call pumpkin genocide. An elderly woman puts our hero pumpkin Jack in to her bin outside. We hold on the bin for a moment as time passes. As it begins to shake, we think this is a moment of Disney magic. The pumpkin is coming alive.

Well, when the bin rolls over and Jack rolls away to freedom (or at least the streets), we reveal it was actually a rowdy drunken couple going at it behind the bin.

And if my mum is reading this, I’m sorry. We will only show ankles. Nothing else.

In the original script, it was a raccoon that was responsible for shaking the bin, but you won’t believe how difficult it is to train a raccoon on a low budget without getting rabies.

Where you have to suspend your belief is that Jack’s facial expressions change between shots. That is how as a character he can have an emotional involvement in the story as he travels on a journey between dark and light.

It is after all a dark comedy. And these are the stories I love and want to make. In The Imitation Games, Alan Turin saves Britain in WW2 with the enigma code, but is arrested for simply being gay. It’s a tragic story and yet it is filled with charming comic moments that makes you skip to the next beat. La Vita Bella is an Italian film that goes from charming romance to holocaust, but it has comic moments in the darkest of places.  These films are my role-models. And if I haven't made you laugh and cry after you have watched the Last Jack O'Lantern, you can turn me into pumpkin soup. Or alternatively, write me strongly worded letter of complaint.

Okay, less about me and pumpkins. Let me introduce to you the team. Drum rolls, foot stamping please.

The Team

Tom Holloway as Adam, the homeless guy

First we have actor Tom Holloway from EastEnders and People do Nothing fame. His first big break was as the lead role in the American feature film The Thompson’s which premiered at Film 4’s Frightfest. He has since featured in the BAFTA award winning director Adrian Sitaru’s film Counterpart, as well as the BAFTA nominated British comedy People Just do Nothing and playing Tom Eden in the BAFTA winning British soap Eastenders.  ​

“I was a Tim Burton fan when I first became interested in films, so the twisted fairytale theme interests me as well as the unlikely buddy love story going on between Jack a pumpkin and Adam, who we played with the idea was a soldier once praised by society but then let down and left on the streets. This unites him with Jack who was similarly idolised during Halloween but then left to literally roll down the street and rot.”​

Jack Stalk as Jack the Pumpkin

Jack was raised on Barnbury farm. He never knew his biological parents, but he was adopted by Charles and Mary Stalk since he was a pip. In adolescence, he shunned the country life for the big bright lights of the city and got picked up by an agent. He has since featured in ‘Hocus Pocus’ and ‘Trick R Treat’, and won over the critics with his performances:

The New Yorker – ‘Jack Nicholson watch your back. There’s a new Jack in town’

Empire – ‘He lights up every film he’s in’

Tom Holloway –  'He's an amazing method actor. He takes being a pumpkin quite literally.'

And In 2015, he was voted sexiest vegetable of the year by Farmer’s Market Monthly.

“ I often get typecast for Halloween films, but when I read the script for the Last Jack O’Lantern, I thought this was a chance to expand my oeuvre in to another holiday: Christmas. Since I got the part, my film phone hasn’t stopped ringing. My agent has already had a phone call from the producers of Elf 3”  – Jack

Danni Nicholls - Music & plays the role of busker

She has one of the best voices I have ever heard live and it’s not just me who appreciates her music. Her Americana sound got her a nomination for UK album of the year at the Americana Music Association awards and her album Mockingbird Lane got air-time on the Bob Harris show on Radio 2.

'She effortlessly slips from smoky soul, folk-pop and heart-wrenching alt-country, all in a rich voice’ - Q magazine.

Danni also has an acting credit in the film as she plays the role of the busker in the opening and closing scene.  As this film doesn’t have any dialogue, music will be an incredibly powerful storytelling tool and each scene will be like miniature music video.

http://danninicholls.com/

Timea & Denis Moldovan as Producer & DOP

Denis and Timea are a married production dream team, making films together for the last three years years. Together they have produced Timea's short 'Tingle' as well as working on promo videos for musician Akara Etteh and French Tuesdays. 

Paolo De Battista as 1st AD 

Paolo has worked on feature-length films Ride By and Cobra, as well as half a dozen short films in the UK. After coordinating large crowds and action sequences with car chases, helicopters, and explosions, pumpkins should not cause too many issues, hopefully!

Ricza Rahman - CG artist & Post

Ricza has recently graduated as a CG artist from Southampton Solent University. She previously worked on 3D architectural visualisation projects of hotels and also created a full CGI trailer for a horror game The Haunted House. 

The intention is to use real pumpkins throughout the film, but as we go past pumpkin season, creating CGI expressions will keep the film production going through winter and spring. 

Sound by Odyssey Production

Odyssey Audio Post Production started as a London based collective of sound designers and composers working in independent film. Since then they have grown into a flourishing small company producing sound and music for a variety of different platforms including their most recent venture into game audio with a nomination in audio design for The Bunker - starring Adam Brown (The Hobbit) & Sarah Greene (Penny Dreadful) at Tiga gaming awards late 2016. 

Will Grave - Writer and Director

Just in case you didn’t believe it, I smile… alot. Just badly on camera.

Having studied Literature and Creative Writing at Warwick University, I come from a screenwriting background. But, in recent years I’ve been looking to push on as a director. As I said earlier, making the Green Light District last year and seeing the BBC media coverage it received, has inspired me to make more films. If you like, you can watch the film here: https://vimeo.com/147874024

Working as a creative in the advertising industry, I have written and creatively directed million pound productions and even broken worlds records.  I have been lucky to work with and learn from great talent, including the prop designers of Games of Thrones and director Sam Brown who directed Jay Z’s ‘On to the Next One’ music video.  When I’m not writing my first feature film and making the Last Jack O’Lantern, I’m working at the Good Agency, who exclusively work on charities. If you want to find out more where my strange imagination takes me to, you can check out my site here:  Watchwilms.com

Show me the money...

I’ve spent hundreds of pounds of my own money getting this short off the ground. 50 noble pumpkins have been sadly lost in the making of the Last Jack O’Lantern and I even tracked down the last pumpkin in Britain in a warehouse in February this year. Sadly, she didn’t make it to March. I am determined to finish this film in her memory.

So far we have shot the opening scene and the end credits involving abandoned Christmas trees, but we have another 5 shoot days to complete Jack’s epic journey to Christmas.

We believe the film deserves to be cinematic, but the equipment is not cheap. We have so far used a Canon 5DMKIII and a Black Magic Micro camera, and we will be looking to hire a Panasonic GH5 alongside using an anamorphic adaptor to get that cinematic look and feel. There is also the cost of getting transport and food for a hungry crew and every now and then paying for talent to do this film justice. A typical shoot day can cost 600 pounds.

Since there is no dialogue in the film, music and sound is even more crucial for telling our story, which is why we are investing £500 in to teaming up with the professional sound company Odyssey. And once the post-production is complete, we have high hopes of the Last Jack O’Lantern doing well on the festival circuit, which is why we are looking to initially invest £500 for festival entries.

We want to keep as much of the film ‘in camera’ as possible, but to make sure we can keep filming beyond pumpkin season we are lucky to be in the presence of a great CG artist in Ricza, who will CG a some of Jack’s expressions for us. The cost will run into the hundreds, but still at a fraction of the industry price.

Phew, after all that money talk, here's some art by the brilliant artist and illustrator Sarah Harrison

GO ON... JOIN US

Still following? Good. So, we need you to be our backing vocalists. The Kelly to our Beyonce. To help get this band off the ground. And with 5% of all funds going to the homeless charity Shelter, we hope you will make this group of plucky film-maker’s dream come true whilst helping to give someone shelter this Christmas.

Perks… you say?

You probably have spotted some of the more unusual ones already.

Along with the signed copies of Danni Nicholl's Mockingbird Lane, my two personal favourites are a 3 course dinner with the lead Jack. He’s shy at first, but opens up after a glass of wine or two. And, also that one pumpkin mad person gets the chance to have a pumpkin version of them self in the film. For less money, you might want to come to the premiere at the Bafta’s HQ next Halloween instead. If you support us, I promise to wear this ridiculous suit on the orange carpet.

Follow our journey on Facebook  and on Twitter 

and if you have any questions drop me an email at willgrave@gmail.com

Have a merry pumpkinmas (it's going to take off trust me)

Love the Last Jack O'Lantern Team
story_txt:
Halloween. Pumpkins. Who cares? 
I know I didn’t until a weird question popped into my head:
What happens to pumpkins after Halloween?
The story quickly unfolded about a pumpkin living on the streets with a homeless man and it’s stuck with me for years. I would tell the story at dinner parties, around family at Christmas and even on a date once (my attempt at small talk). Seeing the genuine surprise and delight of people around me, reacting to his dark but sweet story, I decided to direct the film myself. 
Last year, I wrote and co-directed The Green Light District, a short film about the optimistic outlook of real sex workers in Bristol. Seeing the BBC news coverage it was given, has made me hungry to make films that people will remember. Even on their deathbed. 
For this project, I’m lucky enough to be joined by a team of film-making superheroes, including EasterEnders actor Tom Holloway, Americana musician Danni Nicholls and the husband and wife production team of Denis & Timea Moldovan. They’ve been with me on this project for over a year and have been amazing every step of the way as we develop this little epic. 
 
The Treatment
I'm all for saving pumpkins
after all this is what princesses use to make into carriages
These are the words of Tom Holloway's friend, Irina, after hearing about the film, which I thought was kind of beautiful. The Last Jack O’Lantern is a dark fairytale for modern times. Homelessness has replaced the dragon. The man living on the street, Adam, is a potential knight in shining armour and the beautiful princess is a plump pumpkin who survived Halloween.
And the focus and the way I will shoot the film is all about pumpkins. A world from their perspective. Instead of pumpkins being decorative, it will be people who will play that role in the film’s scenes.
You will see Christmas shoppers passing by Jack, the hero pumpkin and the homeless guy Adam. as well as revellers at Halloween parties in the ‘pumpkin rave' scene. But, in both scenes you will never see their faces. Other than the homeless man, people are on the edge of frame; they’re on periphery. For once, we enter in to a pumpkin’s world.

It’s a cat and mouse world in Tom and Jerry.  The human face is never visible.
Our pumpkin hero Jack does not move on its own accord. It does not talk.  After all, ‘he’ is just a vegetable.
But, the way Adam cares for him. The way we shoot from the pumpkin’s perspective. And through music too. He comes alive.
I’m interested in the way people can feel for inanimate objects, especially through the magic of film. It’s worth checking out Spike Jonze’s ‘Lamp’. It’s a junk of metal, but you are heartless, if you don’t feel like rushing into the streets to give the lamp a home by the end of the advert.

Throughout the Last Jack O'Lantern, we toy with the audience with the idea of magic realism. Is Jack actually alive?
The opening shot is our hero pumpkin with a winter hat on and a spare change cup in front of him. People ignore him, until eventually someone kindly drops him a few pennies. At this point, the homeless man’s hand comes in to frame to raise the cup in acknowledgment. We are back in a very real world. Is the pumpkin just a prop for the homeless man to get more money?
Later in the film, we go back in time to the day after Halloween- a scene we call pumpkin genocide. An elderly woman puts our hero pumpkin Jack in to her bin outside. We hold on the bin for a moment as time passes. As it begins to shake, we think this is a moment of Disney magic. The pumpkin is coming alive.
Well, when the bin rolls over and Jack rolls away to freedom (or at least the streets), we reveal it was actually a rowdy drunken couple going at it behind the bin.
And if my mum is reading this, I’m sorry. We will only show ankles. Nothing else.
In the original script, it was a raccoon that was responsible for shaking the bin, but you won’t believe how difficult it is to train a raccoon on a low budget without getting rabies.
Where you have to suspend your belief is that Jack’s facial expressions change between shots. That is how as a character he can have an emotional involvement in the story as he travels on a journey between dark and light.

It is after all a dark comedy. And these are the stories I love and want to make. In The Imitation Games, Alan Turin saves Britain in WW2 with the enigma code, but is arrested for simply being gay. It’s a tragic story and yet it is filled with charming comic moments that makes you skip to the next beat. La Vita Bella is an Italian film that goes from charming romance to holocaust, but it has comic moments in the darkest of places.  These films are my role-models. And if I haven't made you laugh and cry after you have watched the Last Jack O'Lantern, you can turn me into pumpkin soup. Or alternatively, write me strongly worded letter of complaint.
Okay, less about me and pumpkins. Let me introduce to you the team. Drum rolls, foot stamping please.
The Team
Tom Holloway as Adam, the homeless guy
First we have actor Tom Holloway from EastEnders and People do Nothing fame. His first big break was as the lead role in the American feature film The Thompson’s which premiered at Film 4’s Frightfest. He has since featured in the BAFTA award winning director Adrian Sitaru’s film Counterpart, as well as the BAFTA nominated British comedy People Just do Nothing and playing Tom Eden in the BAFTA winning British soap Eastenders.  ​
“I was a Tim Burton fan when I first became interested in films, so the twisted fairytale theme interests me as well as the unlikely buddy love story going on between Jack a pumpkin and Adam, who we played with the idea was a soldier once praised by society but then let down and left on the streets. This unites him with Jack who was similarly idolised during Halloween but then left to literally roll down the street and rot.”​
Jack Stalk as Jack the Pumpkin
Jack was raised on Barnbury farm. He never knew his biological parents, but he was adopted by Charles and Mary Stalk since he was a pip. In adolescence, he shunned the country life for the big bright lights of the city and got picked up by an agent. He has since featured in ‘Hocus Pocus’ and ‘Trick R Treat’, and won over the critics with his performances:
The New Yorker – ‘Jack Nicholson watch your back. There’s a new Jack in town’
Empire – ‘He lights up every film he’s in’
Tom Holloway –  'He's an amazing method actor. He takes being a pumpkin quite literally.'
And In 2015, he was voted sexiest vegetable of the year by Farmer’s Market Monthly.
“ I often get typecast for Halloween films, but when I read the script for the Last Jack O’Lantern, I thought this was a chance to expand my oeuvre in to another holiday: Christmas. Since I got the part, my film phone hasn’t stopped ringing. My agent has already had a phone call from the producers of Elf 3”  – Jack
Danni Nicholls - Music & plays the role of busker
She has one of the best voices I have ever heard live and it’s not just me who appreciates her music. Her Americana sound got her a nomination for UK album of the year at the Americana Music Association awards and her album Mockingbird Lane got air-time on the Bob Harris show on Radio 2.
'She effortlessly slips from smoky soul, folk-pop and heart-wrenching alt-country, all in a rich voice’ - Q magazine.
Danni also has an acting credit in the film as she plays the role of the busker in the opening and closing scene.  As this film doesn’t have any dialogue, music will be an incredibly powerful storytelling tool and each scene will be like miniature music video.
http://danninicholls.com/
Timea & Denis Moldovan as Producer & DOP
Denis and Timea are a married production dream team, making films together for the last three years years. Together they have produced Timea's short 'Tingle' as well as working on promo videos for musician Akara Etteh and French Tuesdays. 
Paolo De Battista as 1st AD 
Paolo has worked on feature-length films Ride By and Cobra, as well as half a dozen short films in the UK. After coordinating large crowds and action sequences with car chases, helicopters, and explosions, pumpkins should not cause too many issues, hopefully!
Ricza Rahman - CG artist & Post
Ricza has recently graduated as a CG artist from Southampton Solent University. She previously worked on 3D architectural visualisation projects of hotels and also created a full CGI trailer for a horror game The Haunted House. 
The intention is to use real pumpkins throughout the film, but as we go past pumpkin season, creating CGI expressions will keep the film production going through winter and spring. 
Sound by Odyssey Production
Odyssey Audio Post Production started as a London based collective of sound designers and composers working in independent film. Since then they have grown into a flourishing small company producing sound and music for a variety of different platforms including their most recent venture into game audio with a nomination in audio design for The Bunker - starring Adam Brown (The Hobbit) & Sarah Greene (Penny Dreadful) at Tiga gaming awards late 2016. 
Will Grave - Writer and Director
Just in case you didn’t believe it, I smile… alot. Just badly on camera.
Having studied Literature and Creative Writing at Warwick University, I come from a screenwriting background. But, in recent years I’ve been looking to push on as a director. As I said earlier, making the Green Light District last year and seeing the BBC media coverage it received, has inspired me to make more films. If you like, you can watch the film here: https://vimeo.com/147874024
Working as a creative in the advertising industry, I have written and creatively directed million pound productions and even broken worlds records.  I have been lucky to work with and learn from great talent, including the prop designers of Games of Thrones and director Sam Brown who directed Jay Z’s ‘On to the Next One’ music video.  When I’m not writing my first feature film and making the Last Jack O’Lantern, I’m working at the Good Agency, who exclusively work on charities. If you want to find out more where my strange imagination takes me to, you can check out my site here:  Watchwilms.com
Show me the money...

The cost will run into the hundreds, but still at a fraction of the industry price.

Phew, after all that money talk, here's some art by the brilliant artist and illustrator Sarah Harrison
GO ON... JOIN US
Still following? Good. So, we need you to be our backing vocalists. The Kelly to our Beyonce. To help get this band off the ground. And with 5% of all funds going to the homeless charity Shelter, we hope you will make this group of plucky film-maker’s dream come true whilst helping to give someone shelter this Christmas.

You probably have spotted some of the more unusual ones already.
Along with the signed copies of Danni Nicholl's Mockingbird Lane, my two personal favourites are a 3 course dinner with the lead Jack. He’s shy at first, but opens up after a glass of wine or two. story:
The Film 

Departure takes place over the course of one late-Spring day. Throughout the film, we see the events of the day repeated four times through the eyes of each one of the film’s four central characters.

 

ROBERT - YANG MILLER 

Robert is a husband and father who generally avoids the responsibilities of family life. On this day, he must confront his recklessness when he realizes his neglectful actions have taken a dangerous toll on his family.

ANNE - EMILY KEEFE

Anne is a headstrong and impulsive seventeen year old. When it becomes clear that certain secrets she’s kept from her parents are about to come to light, she takes matters into her own hands to protect her future and leave her family behind.

EMILY - PARIS PERRAULT 

Emily is a dutiful police officer with a short fuse who obsesses over taking care of her aging mother. Her patience wears thin as she deals with her sister’s family’s issues, her stressful job, and her mother’s deteriorating state.

LORETTA - ABBY EILAND

Loretta feels like an outsider in her own home. No one in her family appears to show any concern for her—not Robert, Anne, or Emily. However, her drastic decision sends shock waves through the entire family.

 

Who are we?

We are four filmmakers from the US, Turkey, Iran, and Colombia. We’ve spent two years writing, directing, and editing Departure under the careful mentorship of acclaimed filmmaker and Ohio Eminent Scholar in Film, Rajko Grlic. We are excited to finish this film in the coming months so we can put it in front of audiences around the world.

 

When we first pitched the idea, many people told us they thought there was little chanced we’d actually make this film, much less that we would remain friends throughout the process. A film with four writers and directors was a ridiculous idea to most, but we’ve found a way to make our different perspectives work for us instead of against us (and we’re happy to report that we do in fact still like each other).

 

The four of us have bonded throughout this process because of our diverse backgrounds. Our vast experiences have enabled us to see the world through different perspectives, but moreover, they have shown us what it is that binds us all together as humans. Departure has been the ideal vehicle through which we can explore how people view the world differently and ultimately how connected our lives are.

 

       Dustin Jenkins

Dustin grew up in Dublin, Ohio. He graduated from Malone University with a B.A. in Communication Arts, and he also studied at the Los Angeles Film Studies Center. Over the last decade, he has written and directed twelve short films and a feature-length documentary. He will receive his M.F.A. in Film from Ohio University in May 2018, and currently works as a writer in Columbus, Ohio.

 

       Semih Bedir

Semih is originally from Istanbul, Turkey. He received a B.A. in Film and TV from Bahcesehir University. He interned in the Council of Europe's Audiovisual department and worked as an assistant screenwriter on several Turkish TV series. His latest short film, Capital, screened in seven festivals around the world and won three awards. He received his M.F.A. in Film from Ohio University and is pursuing his Ph.D. in Mass Communication there as well.

 

       Shahriar Shafiani

Shahriar is from Tehran, Iran and has been making work as an independent filmmaker, writer, photographer, and musician for the past seven years. He has made films in the Middle East, Europe, and the United States and is proud to have screened his work at esteemed festivals such as AIFVF and the Berlin Short Film Festival. He received his M.F.A. in Film from Ohio University in 2017 and he recently started to pursue a doctoral degree in film at Ohio University.

 

      Daniel Agüera

Daniel was born and raised in Bogotá, Colombia. He moved to the States when he was 18 and majored in Psychology and English at SUNY Albany, and has an M.F.A. in Filmmaking from Ohio University. He has written and directed several short films, has worked as an assistant editor for a few companies, and has published reviews in the Mexican film magazine Cinemania.

 

RAJKO GRLIC - EXECUTIVE PRODUCER

Rajko Grlic was born in 1947 in Zagreb, Croatia. He studied and graduated in film directing at FAMU in Prague, Czech Republic, in 1971, mentored by professor Elmar Klos.

As a director and scriptwriter, he has made twelve feature films, which have been shown in cinemas in every continent. His films have won more than fifty international prizes and have earned numerous nominations – including a nomination for the Palm d’Or. His recent film, The Constitution (2016), won awards at the Montreal World Film Festival, the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, and the Raindance Film Festival. He has also worked on some twenty short films and more than fifteen television documentaries. 

He is the Ohio Eminent Scholar in Film at Ohio University, Athens, OH and Guest Professor of Film at the Art School, University of Nova Gorica, Slovenia. He has taught Film Direction and has delivered lectures and workshops at more than thirty universities in Europe and America. He is a member of the European Film Academy, the Croatian Film Directors' Association, and the American Scriptwriters' Association. His work in film has earned him the Nazor prize, the life achievement award of the City of Denver, and the title of honorary citizen of Montpellier, France.

 

Cast & Crew

We built our team with an amazing cast and crew made up of both talented professionals and student filmmakers.

  • We are indebted to our powerful cast led by Yang Miller, Emily Keefe, Paris Perrault, and Abby Eiland and our supporting cast led by Shelly Delaney, Tim Ashby, Kevin Barbaro, Greg Mason, and many others. Their collective talent, along with that of the rest of the cast, breathed life into our script and added emotional depth and intensity to the project beyond what we could have dreamed.
  • We were able to assemble an incredibly talented crew as well. Michael Arter, Patrick Local, and Justin Kohlas produced the film; our director of photography was the exceptionally talented John Veleta; Alyssa Pearson was the first assistant director; and Helene Siebrits was the art director. These are just a few of the many invaluable members of our team.

  • There is absolutely no way we would have been able to get to this point without the continuing support of the Ohio University Film Division. Students and faculty from both Ohio University’s Film and Theater Divisions filled many of our critical cast and crew positions. We’ve also benefited from Ohio University’s strong Alumni community by bringing on several former OU students who are now working professionals in the film industry.

 

What We Need 

We completed production on Departure last May. We were able to fund the entirety of the shoot by submitting eight successful grant applications, which awarded us over $35,000.

 

However, in order to properly complete the film, we need to hire professional sound editors and mixers, a composer for the film’s score, and a colorist to perform a final color grading of the picture. The minimum required for these services is $15K. We would love to keep pushing past this goal because the more money we raise, the more in depth we can get into these processes so we can produce a more polished final product.


Our stretch goal is $20K, which will allow us to raise enough money to cover promotional costs and festival submission fees so we can share Departure with as many audiences as possible.

 

We ask that you join us on this journey. Here's your chance to support independent filmmaking! If you contribute, you’ll be able to select from exciting perks, and you’ll help us share our story about the importance of human connection with audiences around the globe. 

 

 

Risks & Challenges

At every juncture, when it has seemed impossible to make this film, we’ve put our heads down and come together to get the job done. In addition to the long odds of being four filmmakers with no money, we’ve experienced turmoil in our homelands throughout the time we’ve worked on this project. So far, nothing has stopped us – not civil unrest, protests, coup attempts, or uncertainty concerning visas – and we don’t anticipate anything stopping us now.

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Please follow our journey through social media!
  • Like us at: http://www.facebook.com/Departure-1954358704833199
  • Follow us on Instagram: @departurethefilm
  • Here is a link to our IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt7023278/?ref_=fn_al_tt_2
  • Even if you cannot contribute monetarily, please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread our page through your own social media!

 

Thank you for your support!

These are just a few of the many invaluable members of our team.



There is absolutely no way we would have been able to get to this point without the continuing support of the Ohio University Film Division. Students and faculty from both Ohio University’s Film and Theater Divisions filled many of our critical cast and crew positions. We’ve also benefited from Ohio University’s strong Alumni community by bringing on several former OU students who are now working professionals in the film industry.

 
What We Need 
We completed production on Departure last May. We were able to fund the entirety of the shoot by submitting eight successful grant applications, which awarded us over $35,000. However, in order to properly complete the film, we need to hire professional sound editors and mixers, a composer for the film’s score, and a colorist to perform a final color grading of the picture. The minimum required for these services is $15K. We would love to keep pushing past this goal because the more money we raise, the more in depth we can get into these processes so we can produce a more polished final product.
Our stretch goal is $20K, which will allow us to raise enough money to cover promotional costs and festival submission fees so we can share Departure with as many audiences as possible.
 

We ask that you join us on this journey. Here's your chance to support independent filmmaking! If you contribute, you’ll be able to select from exciting perks, and you’ll help us share our story about the importance of human connection with audiences around the globe. 
 
 
Risks & Challenges
At every juncture, when it has seemed impossible to make this film, we’ve put our heads down and come together to get the job done. In addition to the long odds of being four filmmakers with no money, we’ve experienced turmoil in our homelands throughout the time we’ve worked on this project. So far, nothing has stopped us – not civil unrest, protests, coup attempts, or uncertainty concerning visas – and we don’t anticipate anything stopping us now.

 
Other Ways You Can Help!

Please follow our journey through social media!
Like us at: http://www.facebook.com/Departure-1954358704833199

Follow us on Instagram: @departurethefilm
Here is a link to our IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt7023278/?ref_=fn_al_tt_2

Even if you cannot contribute monetarily, please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread our page through your own social media!

 
Thank you for your support!

story:
THE STORY

Lee Chih-Wei is 23 and has just graduated from Whampoa, Taiwan's Military Academy. He returns home for the first time in 4 years, only to discover that the father he’s been holding a grudge against has died. We learn along the way that his father forced Chih-Wei to join the military and give up his dream of going to University, and when Chih-Wei turned to his mother, she turned her back. Now he has to decide whether to make amends with his mother and the memory of his father, or leave her, and his family name, behind forever.

 

WHY THIS FILM MATTERS

Alvin and Brent (our Producers, you'll meet them in a second) spent a majority of their lives in Hsinchu, Taiwan. However, the brothers noticed early on that the movies they grew up watching weren't Taiwanese. Ever since the 1990s, with the globalization of Taiwan, the authentic experience of being Taiwanese has starting disappearing from its films. Bai Bai is an effort to find what that identity means today, in a world where every male citizen has to serve in the military, and war could be just 100 miles away.

Andrew (our Director), Alvin, and Brent are separated by over 10,000 miles, but work together to create a unique story and vision. Playing to our strengths as director and producers, we are all creating a unified experience that can’t be told anywhere else except for Taiwan.

 

MEET THE TEAM

 

BEHIND THE STORY

Origins, Inspirations, & More

Alvin and Andrew met each other in their first class at NYU (web design), and have been friends ever since. When Andrew found out about Alvin's dream to rebuild the Taiwanese film industry, he dove in headfirst. During a late-night producorial meeting about Andrew's Junior-year film, Alvin suggested they finally make something together, in Taiwan. Over the next year, Andrew was introduced to Taiwan's rich film history, and fell in love with the work of Edward Yang, Hou Hsiao-hsien, and Tsai Ming-liang, among others. While Alvin will always be the biggest fan of Ang Lee, he and Andrew have incorporated all of these influences into Bai Bai.

These are some of the images that Andrew and our DP Alex keep coming back to. Some of them are from Taiwanese films, some of them aren't. All of them, we feel, help capture the essence of Bai Bai:

  • Dust in the Wind (1986) by Dir. Hou Hsiao-Hsien
  • Dodes'ka-den (1970) by Dir. Akira Kurosawa
  • Rhapsody in August (1991) by Dir. Akira Kurosawa
  • Inside Llewyn Davis (2013) by Dir. Ethan and Joel Cohen
  • The Revenant (2015) by Dir. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu
  • Taipei Story (1985) by Dir. Edward Yang
  • A Brighter Summer Day (1991) by Dir. Edward Yang

When the film started picking up momentum, Alvin reached out to his brother and business partner, Brent. Together, they run BSK Productions (www.bskproductions.net), producing films, music videos, music, and concerts in Taiwan and across Asia. Brent, a talented writer and director in his own right, agreed to come on as our Taiwan-based Producer. He and Alvin helped Andrew create the world of Bai Bai, always making sure to keep the story honest to their own experiences.

Now, 12 months after that first brainstorming session, Andrew, Alvin, and Brent are nearly ready to make Bai Bai a reality. We've been officially approved by NYU, and Alvin was lucky enough to be the recipient of NYU's Producers Award, a grant only given to a handful of Producers every year who have proven to be true creative collaborators in the pre-production process. We're almost at the finish line, but we still need support to make it all the way there.

 

BUDGET OVERVIEW

For all of the time and effort we've been given so far, we still need money to get the job done. Below is Bai Bai's current operating budget. We've been working with companies like the HeKuan Equipment Company, a local rental house, to make sure all of our numbers are accurate, and that every penny is stretched as far as it can:

We've been lucky enough to be in touch with several organizations in Taiwan that have been extremely helpful in getting this film made. The first of which is the Ta-Yu Community Center, an organization dedicated to preserving beautiful, old homes in Taiwan. They have offered us the use of their entire facility, including a building for housing the cast and crew, for free! We can't overstate how grateful we are. Below are several photos of the location:

Between their generosity and the financial support we've gotten from NYU, we have managed to raise around $4,000 in preliminary funding. For that reason, we are aiming to raise $10,000 in additional funding from our community, including you!

 

SUPPORT US!

Making a film from scratch is tough, and it can easily get financially difficult for student filmmakers without support. We cannot make Bai Bai come to life without your help. That is a fact. With your support, big or small, we have the ability to tell a story that will hopefully inspire a whole new generation of Taiwanese filmmakers.

For donors who are looking to support our project, please check out the perks we have prepared as a little thank you gift. If we can reach our target, we're confident this movie can be something special. Every extra dollar will help Bai Bai become something even greater!

We also understand that not everyone has money to spare (we're college students too!), but we are just as grateful if you can help us spread the word, link our campaign online, and share it with your friends and family! Any show of support is immensely appreciated!

story:
Blueberries is a deeply intimate story about how Alzheimer’s Disease affects a family.

It follows Will, who returns to his small hometown after his first year in college. He realizes that his mother has been quietly taking care of her own mother, who has Alzheimer’s, and not asking for help when she needs it the most. When the two visit Nana at her assisted living facility, Will realizes it's time for a change.

We believe that telling honest and down-to-earth stories is crucial. Over five million Americans are living with Alzheimer’s, yet there’s a significant lack of films that portray the disease truthfully. We hope that this film will shed light on the realities of Alzheimer’s and all those affected by it, especially the caretakers.

As anyone in this situation knows, professional caretakers often provide 24/7 personal care tasks for little pay. Without the help from these caretakers, these tasks would otherwise take a heavy toll on families everywhere. We have the special opportunity to film in the Providence Personal Care Community, which is an assisted living facility operated by some of the kindest and most hardworking people on the planet. Our goal is to give back to these thankless caretakers. After production, we will donate a portion of our raised funds to the aides at PPCC in Senatobia, Mississippi.

Director's Statement

"Blueberries is the most personal script I’ve ever written. It’s inspired by my experience of witnessing my mother take care of my grandmother with Alzheimer’s. This disease has affected my family immensely and I will portray it as honestly as possible. Blueberries will be filmed entirely in Senatobia and Como, MS. My home state has been the backdrop for every short film I’ve written and directed because they’re all inspired from my real life experiences. I feel that the best way to do my senior thesis film justice is to shoot it in my hometown, in the real locations that inspired the story. Mississippi’s neighboring states have benefited greatly from a booming film industry. Although a short film doesn’t provide as much of an economic boost to a community as a big budget feature film, I hope to help inspire other filmmakers to bring their projects to the beautiful Magnolia State."

- West Givens

Our Budget and Your Contribution

Your contribution allows us to tell this story as honestly and effectively as possible. A full art department budget means that we can bring the vision behind the script to screen. This personal element of this script requires immensely authentic set design.

Transporting cast, crew, and equipment from Georgia to Mississippi is no easy task! Your contribution allows us to ensure that our crew arrives safely, that they are housed, and provided with meals throughout the time of production.

Meet the Crew

Sharing is Caring

We understand that not everyone can contribute to our campaign. The next best thing is to share our campaign with your family and friends. The more people that see our campaign, the higher our chance of reaching our goal!

We can't thank you enough for your support!
