story:
Short Summary

Hello! I'm Julia Perez-Chavez a Mexican-American Filmmaker and Current student at Columbia College Hollywood! I am currently an Intern at Align Pictures and I am a proud member of the Evolve Entertainment Fund Program, awarded by Mayor Eric Garcetti.

I was born and raised in East LA but my family and I moved to Colorado a few years back and now I've returned to study Film and Television Production and Directing with an unofficial minor in Cinematography.

As a senior here at CCH I will be filming my thesis film "When Sparks Fly"

My film is about two teens with rough uprisings and how their friendship slowly falls apart because of distrust and betrayal, these events lead to a cruel unforgettable Prom night.

The film was inspired by an event that happened in East Los Angeles when I was younger. The year before my older sister was heading into Garfield High School, some students burned down the auditorium and some classrooms. My dad being the stern overprotective father, decided that he didn't want any of his kids going into a school with such danger, gang violence, and drugs involved. So he decided to move us to Colorado, in a small town that seemed like a retirement town to be more specific. I always wondered what could have started the fire, and so I decided to write my film about it. I wrote this film to show that men just like women have strong and valid emotions. We're all human and we deal with our troubles and emotions in all kinds of ways. But sometimes the pressure of being a "man" can drive one to the extreme.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's where your contributions will go to:

  • Food: It would be amazing if we can provide warm meals for all the cast and crew of 15 people plus all the Extras! Especially on the Prom day! (Did you know Lunchtime is the most dangerous time of the day! Yup, it can make or break the attitude and performance of everyone on set!
  • Transportation: I would love to be able to pay for everyone's transportation, Gas isn't cheap...especially in California. So I plan on compensating everyone who takes the effort to join and help me create my film!
  • Set Design and Props: Our goal is to make the film and the locations look and feel as authentic as possible. And for the Prom! We need to make is as Fabulous as possible! Streamer, Light, Banners, Balloons, Disco balls!
  • Wardrobe: The clothes our actors will wear must be authentic and real to East Los Angeles style, the age they are, and the year the story is based on, AND Dresses! We gotta dress cast and extras!
  • Locations: With your help, we'd be able to secure awesome locations! A house, a School, and a venue for the Prom! We'd need to get permits and the proper permission to film anywhere in LA.
  • Camera Equipment: In order to film and capture the cool shots we plan on getting, we'd need some cool equipment like easy rigs, stabilizers, Dolly's, and you can't forget the lenses! 
  • Special Effects: In order to start the Fire, (we can't really start a fire) We need Smoke! Lots of it! Fog machines, special effects to recreate fire! How cool with that be?!
  • Contingency: This is emergency money, in case something goes wrong, there will be a lot of people I have to take care of, I have to be two steps ahead and keep everyone safe.

 

WHAT PERKS WILL YOU RECIEVE??

  1. Personalized Thank you!
  2. A shout out on our Instagram page telling everyone how awesome you are!
  3. A role as an Extra in the Film!
  4.  A Copy of the Script and Film!
  5. A role as a Teacher or Student!
  6. An Invite to PROM!
  7. Behind the Scenes Photos!
  8. A chance to be crowned Prom King or Queen!
  9.  Your Name in the Credits of a film!
  10. A role as an Executive Producer!

The Impact

As a Mexican-American Female filmmaker, I want to be able to create and Direct this large production with my team! I was always afraid of raising my voice or speaking up to people or speaking my mind. But when I'm Directing and filming I feel creative, free, and inspired.

I want to create this film about Hispanic struggles, broken bonds, and Betrayal. Troubled Neighborhood and how growing up means growing apart.

We all have been there when we had a bond we thought could not be broken, but at the most unexpected moment, it just ends. I thought it would be interesting to see it from a male point of view and demonstrate how emotional men can be. We all have valid emotions 

It gives me a sense of pride to be creating a film in my home town of East Los Angeles! The culture, music, food, people, and art in the city are inspiring and the stories are worth the listen!

Risks & Challenges

The famous saying follows everyone everywhere, especially if you plan something extensively. "Anything that can go wrong will go wrong" and we have to be ready to handle any issue that comes our way.  But with your Help and support, we can be ready to face any financial challenge to come! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate have no fear! By simply Sharing this video with your Friends, Family, Neighbors, and Teachers, that would be Extremely helpful! 

I appreciate all of you who spent the time to check out my campaign and help support, contribute and Share! 

Thank You, Thank You, Thank You!!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello! I'm Julia Perez-Chavez a Mexican-American Filmmaker and Current student at Columbia College Hollywood! I am currently an Intern at Align Pictures and I am a proud member of the Evolve Entertainment Fund Program, awarded by Mayor Eric Garcetti.
I was born and raised in East LA but my family and I moved to Colorado a few years back and now I've returned to study Film and Television Production and Directing with an unofficial minor in Cinematography.
As a senior here at CCH I will be filming my thesis film "When Sparks Fly"
My film is about two teens with rough uprisings and how their friendship slowly falls apart because of distrust and betrayal, these events lead to a cruel unforgettable Prom night.

The film was inspired by an event that happened in East Los Angeles when I was younger. The year before my older sister was heading into Garfield High School, some students burned down the auditorium and some classrooms. My dad being the stern overprotective father, decided that he didn't want any of his kids going into a school with such danger, gang violence, and drugs involved. So he decided to move us to Colorado, in a small town that seemed like a retirement town to be more specific. I always wondered what could have started the fire, and so I decided to write my film about it. I wrote this film to show that men just like women have strong and valid emotions. We're all human and we deal with our troubles and emotions in all kinds of ways. But sometimes the pressure of being a "man" can drive one to the extreme.




What We Need & What You Get
Here's where your contributions will go to:


Food: It would be amazing if we can provide warm meals for all the cast and crew of 15 people plus all the Extras! Especially on the Prom day! (Did you know Lunchtime is the most dangerous time of the day! Yup, it can make or break the attitude and performance of everyone on set!

Transportation: I would love to be able to pay for everyone's transportation, Gas isn't cheap...especially in California. So I plan on compensating everyone who takes the effort to join and help me create my film!

Set Design and Props: Our goal is to make the film and the locations look and feel as authentic as possible. And for the Prom! We need to make is as Fabulous as possible! Streamer, Light, Banners, Balloons, Disco balls!

Wardrobe: The clothes our actors will wear must be authentic and real to East Los Angeles style, the age they are, and the year the story is based on, AND Dresses! We gotta dress cast and extras!

Locations: With your help, we'd be able to secure awesome locations! A house, a School, and a venue for the Prom! We'd need to get permits and the proper permission to film anywhere in LA.

Camera Equipment: In order to film and capture the cool shots we plan on getting, we'd need some cool equipment like easy rigs, stabilizers, Dolly's, and you can't forget the lenses! 

Special Effects: In order to start the Fire, (we can't really start a fire) We need Smoke! Lots of it! Fog machines, special effects to recreate fire! How cool with that be?!

Contingency: This is emergency money, in case something goes wrong, there will be a lot of people I have to take care of, I have to be two steps ahead and keep everyone safe.

 
WHAT PERKS WILL YOU RECIEVE??

Personalized Thank you!
A shout out on our Instagram page telling everyone how awesome you are!
A role as an Extra in the Film!
 A Copy of the Script and Film!
A role as a Teacher or Student!
An Invite to PROM!
Behind the Scenes Photos!
A chance to be crowned Prom King or Queen!
 Your Name in the Credits of a film!
A role as an Executive Producer!


The Impact
As a Mexican-American Female filmmaker, I want to be able to create and Direct this large production with my team! I was always afraid of raising my voice or speaking up to people or speaking my mind. But when I'm Directing and filming I feel creative, free, and inspired.
I want to create this film about Hispanic struggles, broken bonds, and Betrayal. Troubled Neighborhood and how growing up means growing apart.
We all have been there when we had a bond we thought could not be broken, but at the most unexpected moment, it just ends. I thought it would be interesting to see it from a male point of view and demonstrate how emotional men can be. We all have valid emotions 
It gives me a sense of pride to be creating a film in my home town of East Los Angeles! The culture, music, food, people, and art in the city are inspiring and the stories are worth the listen!

Risks & Challenges
The famous saying follows everyone everywhere, especially if you plan something extensively. "Anything that can go wrong will go wrong" and we have to be ready to handle any issue that comes our way.  But with your Help and support, we can be ready to face any financial challenge to come! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate have no fear! By simply Sharing this video with your Friends, Family, Neighbors, and Teachers, that would be Extremely helpful! 
I appreciate all of you who spent the time to check out my campaign and help support, contribute and Share! 
Thank You, Thank You, Thank You!!

story:
BACKSTORY:
In July 2003, I drove my moving truck out of the mountains and into Salt Lake City. Before arriving at my new apartment, I saw a bunch of Mormons burning American flags. So I pulled over, grabbed my camera and began shooting footage. And I didn't turn the camera off for 3 years.

My original idea, 12 years ago, was to compile an anthology of strange, funny and heartbreaking stories into one big documentary film about Utah.


Filming at a Utah mall in 2004 

Shooting broll at a murder scene in 2003


Conducting an interview of a Salt Lake City strip club owner


Everything was coming together great, but then Michael Moore came to town.

In 2004, I shot, edited, produced and directed by first feature film "This Divided State" about filmmaker Michael Moore's controversial visit to Orem, UT 2 weeks before the Bush/Kerry presidential election. Originally, this event was going to be a just another entry in my anthology, but it quickly grew into something of its own. The film garnered critical success and I spent the next 2 years traveling the world promoting it.



I then went on to direct 2 more feature documentaries, "Killer at Large" (2008) and "8: The Mormon Proposition" (2010). I then shot/edited/produced a docu-mini-series for MTV called "Kesha: My Crazy Beautiful Life" (2013).

In 2015, I was digging through my storage closet and found 2 large boxes full of miniDV tapes.


One box of raw footage

I spent 4 months slowly ripping all the footage. I poured through every interview, every shot, and every story. I laughed, cried and reminisced. Some of this stuff was just too good to remain forever locked away in storage. I wanted people to see it.
So here I am, 12 years later, descending out of the mountains and into the valley once more.

THE RELEASE PLAN:
Since I never actually completed production, some of these stories exist as small fragments of a bigger picture.

An official website will host all the videos.

I have at least 15 stories including:

- The Crazy Goat Saloon, the death of the Salt Lake City strip club
- A Double Murder in a Murderless Town
- A Good Ole Community Flag Burning
- Walmart Closes Down a Mormon Pioneer
- Street Preachers vs. Clowns: Round One
- The Spanish Fork Rodeo
- The Most Patriotic Baby Contest
- The High School Bridal Fair
- A Healing Ceremony at the Mountain Meadows Massacre
- A Quaint Little Town Infested With Poop
- The Naughty Words Vandal of Lehi, UT
- An Angry Rabbi Sends Black People to Utah

I estimate the running time of each entry will be 2 to 5 minutes long.

I will launch the stories, one at a time, starting around December 2015.

FUNDS:
98% of the footage was shot 12 years ago. But I'll need to spend money on the following:
- Stock footage licensing (to fill in the holes)
- Music licensing
- Archive photo licensing
- Additional footage (shooting broll)
- Web hosting
- Web design
- Quick legal counsel. It's been 12 years so I need someone to look at my old release forms and paperwork.

story:
Hello my name is Keith Jackson, I'm a director from VA. I've worked int the film industry for 11 years.

Moe Hendrix is a hip hop artist friend of mine from VA. He has moved to Denver to pursue his career. We have worked together on other music videos of his fellow artists. Moe trying to do his best to promote his brand and new album approached me for a music video. Music videos or production of any kind can be pricey. It takes equipment, camera, lights and insurance for the equipment. I'm not here trying to make money. I'm just trying to help a friend, Moe. However he needs funds to take care of any costs the video will incur. Pleas help if you can. Thanks so much in advance.
Bests
Keith Jackson

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story: We are fundraising to finish the post-production of this short film. We need your help to reach our goal of $600 that will help pay for everything from editing to pickup shots to marketing and finally our premiere. We are offering some great rewards for any donation you make, Everything from free tickets to our premiere red carpet event, to singing lessons and so much more. So dig deep and give what you can to help make this amazing story reach the lives of others!

story:
"Lizzy and Chuck find that, in order to discover who they are, they must let go of the secrets they keep."

A light hearted comedic romp quickly spirals into a dark tragedy, as secrets are revealed (or exposed), and lives are changed dramatically.



In a world that has become complicit in the culture of secrecy, we hope to, through a mixture of comedy and drama, examine the destructive nature of these secrets to the lives of those around us.

This film is about more than hiding, however. We also follow a full cast of characters who really come to terms with their identities, and the outside factors that both assist and detract from our true understanding.

We look at how the way we grow up shapes our views of ourselves, by diving into the small mindedness of some Midwestern residents on the subject of sex and sexuality, as well as the way that some religious groups view/condemn it.  We also jump head first into the subject of depression, addiction, and loss.



LIZZY: Megan Weyant


CHUCK: 

Colton Walters



TAYLOR: Anastasia August

TINA: Becky Neuroth

JESS: Sabrina Kinney


DAVE: Ben Gothier




Writer/Director: Joe Harris

Born in Omaha, Nebraska, Joe began as a self-taught independent filmmaker. His earliest film is...embarrassing, but has a ton of heart. [HINT: You can unlock it through one of our perks]

Through these early experiences, none of which were successful, Joe really began to appreciate the hard work that went into making a good film.

He shipped himself off to Columbia College Chicago, where he graduated with a degree in Film/Video.

Returning to Omaha, he teamed up with three other amazing people, and together they began work under the banner of Pigboat Productions, and later Ignite Life Media. With Pigboat Productions, he directed “Life at Grandpa’s,” using all local talent and crew. He has also directed several short films.

 [HINT: You can get the whole collection through one of our perks!]

Assistant Director: Eric Green

Director of Photography: Guy S. White

Camera Operator: Molly Grant-Leanna


         


Ignite Life Media has embarked on its first feature film as a company, but this is not our first film. We have done short films, including: 


               
The Bargain (2015)               Unusual Means (2015)


We previously operated under the banner of Pigboat Productions, and have made films such as:


Life at Grandpa's (2009)

Sun For Sorrow (2010) 


With Pigboat Productions, we shot our first feature, “Life at Grandpa’s”, with no money, no feature length experience, and no real vision. 

It was a difficult run, but we completed a film that we are proud of, warts and all. It also gave us a basis on which to start improvements.

We have since worked separately to consistently get better at our individual crafts.

Upon the christening of Ignite Life Media, the goal was simple. Tell stories that are about real life and to inspire change in life, whether it is a positive change, or a warning against negative change/showing repercussions of a negative change.

The idea behind the films that we've done have all been to ignite something in the lives of the people that watch them, and to ignite the passions of people that want to express themselves through the various avenues provided in production.

That is what will set One Wandering Thought apart from our previous work.

We are altering our approach to avoid the problems of the previous feature. We are planning smarter for production.

 We are also bringing aboard Amelia Peterson, a skilled editor, with many years of professional experience. We are confident that she will handle the project with the care and respect it deserves.



We are all doing this out of a love for the art form, but for the countless hours that will be put into the project, we want to show our support in a more tangible way.


Making a movie is a fun and collaborative experience that the people involved will always remember so we've created a list of perks for everyone to take advantage of. From digital downloads and credit in the film to personalized videos and set visitations, we want you to be part of this experience!

So far, we have financed the film out of our own savings, and have always been very conscious of frugality and efficiency of each dollar we spend. However, we want to make sure we can maintain this momentum through the remainder of the film.


The perks are listed as US only, but we are able to make exceptions. Just give us a shout out on our Facebook page, or through this, and we will make sure we can take care of you if you help support us.


We have projected an initial goal of $3,000.
 


This campaign is designed to initially raise the funds for production alone.  This will allows us to cover the basic costs of production.



So once, with your support, we hit our initial goal, we will set a stretch goal of $5,000.



This will allow us to pay our main talent a little better, as well as take care of our dedicated crew, and beef up the amount we can pump into production design.



Once we can pay our main cast & crew, we will push ahead toward a goal of $10,000. 



This will help us to cover post-production costs, and initial distribution, as well as, once again, increase the amount we can put into giving this film a unique look.



When this goal has been met, we will strive for a goal of $20,000. 



This will ensure that we can compensate all of our major players, and bring more value to the overall look and feel of the film.  This will also help us to take better care of the film on the back end.



We know that times are tough, and there are a million things you can invest in.

This film could be shot on no budget, with bland sets, and average production quality, but that isn't fair to you the viewer, the cast and crew that are dedicating their time, or to the story itself.

We want to be able to fill the screen with production value, to create a more rich and believable world.

Everyone will be able to see a running, live breakdown of where the funds go for this film on our website, and on this page, if they wish.

In the interest of full transparency, we want you to know that every penny donated to this campaign will go to what you see on the screen when we have a completed project.



Once again, we know that not everyone can afford to give, what with the economy and all that, but there are other (just as important) ways to help as well!

If you have a Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, email, website, bulletin board, megaphone, mouth, or even a Myspace (…maybe?), then you can help us out by spreading the word.

The more people we can reach, the better we can do with this project. The more people that see this page, the better publicity and exposure we can receive, and the better the film can be.

In keeping with our philosophy, we encourage, and welcome to participate in our projects, anyone with a passion for acting, lighting, makeup, writing, stunts, singing, or any other creative expression as it relates to film & media.

If you have passion, and want to have a good time doing what you love, we want you.

We want to ignite the passion that you have, and use it however we can to benefit everyone involved.

In the end, we want everyone to leave having gained something. Whether it is valuable experiences, fond memories, a feeling that you can't shake, or, most importantly right now, an adventure on film that will reignite a passion in your lives.

That is what this is really about. Lighting the fire that drives you and keeping it lit. Igniting lives together through art.

Thank you for reading, and thank you for your continued support.

Let's make a movie!

story:
Synopsis

For several months, Arthur, an elderly retired musician, has been trying desperately to make his Alzheimer's -stricken Filipino wife, Dorothy remember him. His daughter, Carol, decides that it's best to send them both to a home care facility even though he tries to convince her that he can take care of her on his own.

On the night before they are to move out, he finds a old nipa hut-shaped music box that plays a Filipino nursery rhyme, Bahay Kubo. And when Dorothy, hears it, it somehow triggers bits and pieces of her memory.

With this musical discovery, Arthur hopes to reconnect with his wife. But will this suffice?

What does Mahal Mean?

Mahal is a Filipino word that has two meanings. Mahal as a noun is a term of affection  akin to "sweetheart", "honey" or "love". Mahal as an adjective means expensive.

Why am I telling this story?

The basic premise of the script was a brainchild of myself and Andrew Zimmerman in our Ideation and Theme class back at Columbia College Chicago. Andrew had a personal experience with Alzheimer's in his family and was very much interested in the initial theme of atonement. 

While I may not have a close encounter with Alzheimer's and Dementia in my family, I was able to relate the  theme with the unexpected passing of my Mom in 2005 in the Philippines. When she passed away, I was in Singapore studying and I didn't get the chance to see her in her deathbed.

Writing the script for Mahal was therapeutic as it  became my love letter to my Mom. This is why this film is more than just my thesis film. It is my way of honoring my Mom, Estrella.

What your support will do.

We are almost there!
When we set out to do the film, most people were generous enough to share their talents and skills. Through out the whole process, we have managed to overcome hurdles in trying to produce a quality short film with such a limited budget. The above breakdown represents some of the expenses that we need to address in the hopes of finishing MAHAL.
We are excited to have you onboard to help us take Mahal make the rounds of international festivals next year.

The Mahal Team

Jay Españo – Writer/ Director


Jay’s cosmopolitan journey  as actor, singer and director has led him to perform and collaborate in more than 70 productions with some of the most respected theater companies in the Asian region as well as dabbling in film and television.

A recent graduate of Columbia College Chicago with a Masters in Film Directing, Mahal is his final thesis film. Jay is attracted to character driven scripts with unexpected twists at the end. He believes that life is a never ending unexpected twists and turns and is determined to visually catch that essence of life on screen.

Gerardo Duran – Producer 

Born and raised in the south side of Chicago, Gerardo has had to face an upward battle; driven solely by his passion for cinema, Gerardo founded his past high-school’s first film club. He now returns to teach the class. 

He has also worked closely with the Art Institute of Chicago for three years where he was hired to create various short films. He is an actor, writer, producer and assistant director. He is thorough, extremely organized, and a commander on set. Gerardo has been a First Assistant Director for over 5 Short films at Columbia College Chicago and a line producer for another 3. Gerardo Duran is a realist, and will make this film project more than just an idea, he will make it a reality.

Tony Santiago – Cinematographer

A graduate of Columbia College Chicago with a concentration in Cinematography, Tony's experience in school gave him a well developed perspective balance of both the impact & motivation of lighting techniques as well as the delicate, subtle intricacies of camera work. Applying these skills to the professional world, Tony has worked on everything from music videos, short comedy sketches, industrial, & web commercials, all the way to national commercials and feature length films.

Currently, he is a professor at Columbia College Chicago teaching lighting for filmmakers. Additionally, his technical expertise & knowledge of motion picture lighting has placed him as the Studio Coordinator for Columbia College's new 36,000 square foot film production facility. Ultimately, it is his creative eye, excellent teamwork, personality, & masterful ability to tell a story through motion picture that make him well sought out by many other creative & ambitious filmmakers. 

Jesse Lucas – Composer

Jesse is a multi-awarded composer for film, television, theater and dance. He studied composition at the University of the Philippines’ College of Music under the tutelage of maestros Josefino Toledo and Ryan Cayabyab. Some fine examples of his work can be found in the field of Philippine dramatic arts as he has worked with the premiere theater and ballet companies of the country.  

His awards include GAWAD URIAN, YOUNG CRITICS CIRCLE, STAR, FAMAS (Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Science), GAWAD TANGLAW and ALIW and Best Music at the 2005 Screamfest International Film Festival in Los Angeles, California. In 2010, he was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame for Best Music.

Angela Estrada – Editor

Angela is an editing student at Columbia College Chicago. Born and raised in Chicago, she loves working with the people who’ve come from all over, connecting with them through the messages of projects likeMAHAL. She loves to draw, and grew up as a voracious reader. Having edited in her free time for the last 5 years, she began her career in extra-curricular video editing after taking on a project for her friend her first year. Now she is looking at more short film opportunities, including paid nonfiction and trailer/commercial work.

Tony Noice as Arthur

Tony Noice has been an actor for over 50 years, having appeared in dozens of productions in all media. Favorite roles include: Grandpa Vanderhof in YOU CAN’T TAKE IT WITH YOU and Leonato in MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING. 

Tony is a proud member of Actors Equity Association, the Screen Actors Guild, and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. In a parallel career, he has been at the forefront of research using acting techniques to lower risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease. Along with his wife, Helga, a cognitive psychologist, he has published dozens of articles and books on the intersection of theatre and cognition and received four multi-year grants from the National Institutes of Health.

Madeleine Nicolas as Dorothy

Madeleine is a veteran film, television and theatre actor from the Philippines where she honed her craft with some of the best theater companies. Her versatility landed her in significant productions  such as The Vagina Monologues ( in English and Filipino), Stephen Sondheim’s Into the Woods,  V-Day Manila and One Billion Rising, Marsinah Accuses, Fili ( performed in Thailand), The Coffee Shop Within the Play (written and directed by Naohiko Umewaka, a Japanese Noh master).

Madeleine was the lead actress in the short film, Pasahero directed by Mario Celada. She was casted in the films, Captive, with French actress, Isabelle Huppert, directed by acclaimed director Brillante Mendoza, and in Universal Studios’ Bourne Legacy with Jeremy Renner and Rachel Weizs, directed by Tony Gilroy. In 2014, she played the Headmistress in “A Kidnapping” for BBC Radio4 Drama directed by John Dryden under Goldhawk Productions. 

Olga Natividad as Carol


One of Philippine theater’s finest leading ladies, Olga was a member of Tanghalang Pilipino Actors Company headquartered at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. She trained with various local acclaimed acting teachers as well as visiting guest artists. On stage she has tackled memorable classic roles in Shakespeare, Ibsen, Chekhov, Brecht and Williams among others. On television she has guested on numerous soap operas and on film she has worked with some of the best directors in the Philippines such as Marilou Diaz-Abaya,  Mike de Leon , Raymond Red and Tikoy Aguiluz, to name a few.

Her unique approach to the roles she does earned her multiple awards and nominations, the latest was a Best actress nomination from Gawad Urian for her work in Mga Dayo. 

Olga will be seen next in the Devin Rice’s feature Being Black Enough slated for 2016.

Peyton Shaffer as Maddie 

Peyton has performed on many professional stages in the Chicago area. Some  of her past productions are Mary Poppins (Jane Banks), Music Man (Amaryllis), Annie (Kate) and A Christmas Story (Nancy) at the Paramount Theatre; Seussical (Jojo), LesMis (young Eponine) and Billy Elliot (Debbie) at Drury Lane Theater; Fiddler on the Roof (Bielke) and Annie Get Your Gun with Light Opera Works. 

She recently  concluded playing as 'Adam' in the play Merchild at the 16th Street Theater in Berwyn. Peyton was also featured in the Columbia College MFA film 'Tread' (directed by Laura Baker). The current 8th grader plans to continue pursuing a career in film/theatre for as long as possible!


Mahal Cast and Crew

Other Ways You Can Help

The fact that you took the time to view this campaign means a lot to us. Please spread the word out there to your friends and families .

Share this IndieGogo campaign.

Share  and like our Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/MAHAL-1649777738569920/
story_txt:
Synopsis For several months, Arthur, an elderly retired musician, has been trying desperately to make his Alzheimer's -stricken Filipino wife, Dorothy remember him. His daughter, Carol, decides that it's best to send them both to a home care facility even though he tries to convince her that he can take care of her on his own.
On the night before they are to move out, he finds a old nipa hut-shaped music box that plays a Filipino nursery rhyme, Bahay Kubo. And when Dorothy, hears it, it somehow triggers bits and pieces of her memory.
With this musical discovery, Arthur hopes to reconnect with his wife. But will this suffice?

What does Mahal Mean?
Mahal is a Filipino word that has two meanings. Mahal as a noun is a term of affection  akin to "sweetheart", "honey" or "love". Mahal as an adjective means expensive.

Why am I telling this story?
The basic premise of the script was a brainchild of myself and Andrew Zimmerman in our Ideation and Theme class back at Columbia College Chicago. Andrew had a personal experience with Alzheimer's in his family and was very much interested in the initial theme of atonement.

story:
My birthday is a little less than a month away. I am literally surviving off of a dollar and a dream and it would make me so completely happy if you could help me get closer to that dream! Here's how you can help!

As many know, I have relocated to Atlanta, GA to follow my dreams of being a screenwriter/producer/director/ media mogul/Oprah/Spike Lee/Spielberg/Beyonce. Sorry, I got carried away. 

I am in the process of producing my own series to be pitched to major television networks. However, I need some assistance with paying for studio time to interview our guests. I am trying to raise $1000 by September 15, 2015 to pay the crew that will be shooting my newest project. I can't reveal too many details about the project itself yet, but trust me, it is going to be amazing.

I can't imagine a better birthday gift than to be able to move one step closer to my dreams and with your help, I'll get there! No gift is too small and if you can't give monetarily, I'm accepting prayers! 

Thank You in advance beautiful people!
-LANA DOT

story:
Short Summary

Hello my name is April Tylon Warren and the name of my project is called Sunshine day the movie. It is a period piece film that brings awareness to mental illness, domestic violence and suicide. I am very passionate about this project because it is based on a true story. I'm very privileged to have Director Lawrence Lee Wallace and the entire Deep Production crew along with a very talented cast to help me with brining this project to life. So far we were able to put together a teaser/trailer for the movie and with the help and generous donations of our supporters you can help to make this production a success. I am asking that you donate whatever you can. Your donations will go towards; production, locations, hair and makeup for the cast of Sunshine Day, special effects and props just to name a few.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $8,000 within the next 40 days to ensure that "Sunshine Day" doesn't just meet the expectations of our fans and supporters but exceeds them. Your generous donations will help assist with production cost, locations, hair and makeup for the cast of Sunshine Day, props and special effects just to name a few. No donation will go unrecognized.

Donate $5 and receive a thank you from the entire cast and crew. 


 Donate $10 and receive your name in the end credits of Sunshine Day under a very special thank you!


 Donate $15 and receive your picture added to the official Sunshine Day Facebook movie page in the hall of fame album.


 Donate $20 two for on perk. Get your name in the credits and your picture on the official Facebook movie page.


 Donate $30 and receive a digital download. You will receive a digital download of the film before it is released! USA only sorry.


 Donate $40 receive a signed DVD from the writer and executive producer of this true story mailed straight to your door!


 Donate $50 and we will list your business or service in the end of the credits of this motion picture for he world to see. Business names, address, phone number and website.


 Donate $100 and receive a movie poster. A signed 24 by 36 movie poster of the film. Signed by the writer and executive producer of this true story mailed straight to your door!


 Donate $200 come and hang out on the set of Sunshine Day! Be our special guest on the film set for an entire day of filming in Chicago. Watch all the action, meet the cast and have lunch and or dinner with us. Must provide your own transportation to and from the set. Out of towners must provide their own room and board. Only 20 of these perks available.


 Donate $300 come party with us at the exclusive VIP private wrap party in Chicago! Free food! Must provide your own transportation to and from club. Out of towners must provide their own room and board.


 Donate $1000 and receive associate producer credit. Your name credited as Associate Producer in the end of title credits, IMDB credits as well as entrance to the VIP wrap party and premier screening. 3 available.


 Donate $5000 Co Executive Producer. Your name credited as Co- Executive Producer in the end title credits, IMDB credits as well as entrance to the VIP wrap party and premier screening. 3 available.

The Impact

 With your support and  donations a lot of lives will be saved and people all across the world will be more aware of some of the early signs of mental illness, people who are in abusive relationships will be more inspired than ever before to walk away and people who may be having thoughts of suicide will take the necessary steps to get help after watching this dramatic true story. I truly feel that Sunshine Day was meant to save lives and I will stop at nothing to make sure at least one life is saved.

Risks & Challenges

 

I personally faced many challenges while writing this piece and having the project brought to life. Writing “Sunshine Day” opened up a lot of old wounds and unwanted memories of a tragedy that happen to my entire family when I was just five years old. I started writing Sunshine Day because I felt that it may be therapeutic for me but after completing the script I found it to be far more than that. I developed the courage to finally talk about what happened that night to family and friends. I found that my story brought hope to some and encouraged others which led me to seek out a production crew so that my screen play can be turned into a movie. I know that by making this film a lot of lives will be saved and that's what keeps me inspired.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Others way you can help is by spreading the word and inviting your friends to like our Facebook, twitter and instagram page. Thank you!

story:
We are three actresses Janine Gateland, Catherine Eure and Rachel Ryling who are producing the short thriller F***, Marry, Kill.  Created and written by us, we can't wait to tell you all about it and take you on our journey in getting this awesome film made!


What is the film about?
F***, Marry, Kill is a short thriller, directed by Scott Donovan.  The story follows three sisters traveling through the Mojave Desert on their way to their brothers wedding.

A sinister turn of events leads them to a twisted, maddening town where a psychotic, cult-like community kidnaps women and forces them to marry, procreate or be sacrificed.  These residents seem hell bent on making it their final destination.


Why back our film?

We have a wonderful script, concept, amazing locations, fabulous cast & crew, and now awesome footage.  Some of the cast include Timothy Carhart known for "Thelma and Louise", "Ghostbusters", "The Hunt for Red October"  and "Witness".  We are also pleased to say we have the lovely Lorna Scott known for "Wanted", "Little Britain USA", "The Guilt Trip", "Little Boy", "Sorded Lives" and HBO TV series "True Blood".

We are half way there to getting this funded and need a little of your help.


Who we are

Janine Gateland 

Janine is so pleased to be finally creating her own work. She is the executive producer and writer of F***, Marry, Kill and is also playing the leading role ‘Tiffany Forbes’.

British born and London drama school trained, Janine went on to appear in London's West End at The Soho Theater, The Criterion Theater and The Courtyard Theater in "Forget me Knot" and "Twelfth Night" at The Tabard Theater. She has worked on many successful films including "The Test"; which was taken to Cannes Film Festival. In addition, she shot a British national commercial for "Nintendo Wii" and a U.S national commercial for "Disney".  Currently in post-production for the horror "The Closing" and in pre-production for the leading role 'Sarah Adams' in romantic comedy "Let's Just Do It".


Rachel Ryling

Rachel Ryling was born in Nashville, Tennessee and is the daughter of a military officer.  Upon graduation she moved to Los Angeles and entered the Liberal Arts program at Pepperdine University to pursue her career as an actress. 

From there she has worked on various independent films and recently attended Cannes Film festival due to her role 'Lucille' in the feature "Western Religion".  She has also been cast as 'Veronica Stampler' in the popular web series "The Adventures of Velvet Prozak".

She is so pleased to now be involved in this project which will solidify her status as a triple threat in the industry as she is credited as a writer, producer, and actress on this film.


Catherine Eure

Catherine Eure is thrilled to be producing, writing and acting in F***, Marry, Kill alongside Rachel Ryling and Janine Gateland.  Her love of the horror/thriller genre and her desire to create a girl-powered production are married thanks to the journey of this film.  

A North Carolina native, Catherine grew up performing in musical theater and moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in film and TV.  She’s worked in  many independent feature films and has studied acting for most of her life, including training at The Ivana Chubbuck Studio, Stella Adler and The Lee Strasberg Institute.  This project brings her passions for all things creepy, creative control, feminism, and filmmaking  together and she couldn’t be more excited.

Claude Duhamel

Claude Duhamel, born in Montreal, Quebec, is a Canadian film and television actor. He is known for his work on “Valentine", "Destination Vegas", "Dawn Rider" and “Western Religion”.

He studied at the Montreal Actor Studio for 3 years doing mostly improv and theater. Claude pursued his career in Vancouver where he compiled more than 50 Television and Film credits and made a name for himself playing eccentric and dark characters through the next decade. Claude Duhamel continues to keep his dream alive working as a successful actor. He is no stranger to intriguing characters with diverse accents, capable transforming into a chameleon like presence on screen.

He maintains residency in Los Angeles, Vancouver and Montreal.


Timothy Carhart

Timothy co-founded THE AUDITION CENTER in Chicago in his twenties and was one of its original teachers in that highly successful school. He settled in New York and quickly started working both Off and On Broadway, appearing in leading roles opposite Alec Baldwin and Jessica Lange in ”A Streetcar Named Desire”, playing Mitch, at The Berrymore Theatre on Broadway, for six months. Timothy appeared in an adaptation of “The Hitch-Hikers”, opposite Elizabeth McGovern and Francais Fisher at The WPA Theatre.  In addition, leading roles twice at The Manhattan Theatre Club in original productions of “By The Sea, By The Sea”, penned by Terrance McNally, Lanford Wilson and Joe Pintauro, as well as the original production of “The day room” scripted by Don Delillo, from his bestselling book and opposite Mary Beth Hurt and the late JT Walsh.  Some other professional stage work in New York includes work at Manhattan Punch Line Theatre, Playwrights Horozons Theatre, and “The Ballad of Soapy Smith”by Michael Weller, with Chris Cooper at The New York Shakespeare Festival.  Tim also played the lead in John Bishop’s, “The Harvesting” at The Circle Repertory Company, of which he was a member. 

Some film credits include: “Ghostbusters”, “Witness”, “Working Girl”, “Thelma and Louise”, “The Hunt For Red October”, “Red Rock West”, “Beverly Hills Cop III”, and “Black Sheep”.  Many TV shows including: “Thirtysomething”, “X-Files”, “CSI”, (Marg Helgenberger’s ex), “Lie To Me”, “Standoff”, “Wanted”, “Judging Amy”, “Frasier”, and “24”.



Lorna Scott

We are absolutely honored to have this lady in our cast!

Lorna Scott is most often recognized as James McAvoy's Stapler-wielding boss-from hell in the 2008 summer blockbuster "Wanted” with Angelina Jolie, Morgan Freeman, and Chris Pratt.  Her roles in high profile projects like "Little Britain U.S.A” for HBO as a troupe member and in last year's "The Guilt Trip" as the waitress that helps Barbra Streisand eat her way to glory, have earned the veteran character actress a stellar reputation with a bevy of high-profile projects completed including her latest film, "Little Boy", with Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson.

Lorna's wide range of roles in the past years include a pivotal cameo in the highly-rated series "True Blood" (HBO),  the co-star to Faith Ford in the Hallmark Movie Channel’s “A Kiss At Midnight" with Dyan Cannon and Hal Linden, and Bob Saget’s salty neighbor in the ABC sitcom “Surviving Suburbia".  Her starring role as Vera Lisso in Del Shores hysterical cult hit "Sordid Lives"  ( for which she did the stage version, the film, and the LOGO television series) earned her a much cherished fan pick for the character the fans wanted to see more of. Her next film in that series, "A Sordid Wedding”, begins shooting this Fall for the amazing amount of fans that have made “Sordid Lives” such a success — some of whom have seen the original film over 400 times! 


Paul Duke

Standing 6'6" with an extreme athletic build, Paul Duke is a talent who’s difficult to overlook. He speaks four languages (Dutch, English, French and German), along with several dialects, making him incredibly versatile for international characters. 

Duke made his professional debut  in three successful Belgian television series while earning a degree in International & European law. After his graduation Duke moved to Los Angeles to train at the world-renowned Lee Strasberg Theatre Institute as well as at the Beverly Hills Playhouse with Milton Katselas.  He continued his love for theatre in the U.S. by performing on several Los Angeles productions (“Wait until Dark”, “The Firebugs” and “Pvt.Wars”), while successfully adding to his television and film credits.  He was most recently seen in a Lead Role in the first original show from Yahoo! “Sin City Saints” as well as a Recurring Role on “NCIS:LA”.


Meet some of the characters

     Jessica                Carrie              Tiffany

Jessica, Carrie and Tiffany are 3 siblings, all from LA but now live in different states across the US. They are all very different in personality; so going on this road trip to their brother’s wedding may be a recipe for disaster, until town folk of Lake Isabella step in to the mix.

Janine Gateland as Tiffany Forbes

32 year old Tiffany Forbes is a Casino manager at the Tropicana Resort and Casino in Las Vegas. Since her failed marriage from her cheating husband, Tiffany has been on a downward spiral finding a new fling every week!

Tiffany hasn’t seen her sisters in over a year since the disastrous wedding, and now shamefully faces the music of her past mess up before plunged into a messy desert disaster. 

Rachel Ryling as Jessica Forbes

Jessica Forbes is 30 years old and born and raised in Los Angeles.  An aspiring actress by day and bartender by night. Jessica the fiery risk taker, takes her sisters on a ride through the Mojave desert they will never forget!

Catherine Eure as Carrie Forbes

Carrie Forbes is a 24 year old Art Student at the North Carolina School of the Arts.  She is the baby of the family, and often, even though she’s the youngest, is the peace-maker, the voice of reason.  Their journey though the desert sets Carrie keeping them all together in more ways than one.

Claude Duhamel as Stone Walker

Stone is Tiffany’s latest squeeze; he met her at one of his gigs.  Pretends to lead a successful rock star lifestyle but is really a drug dealer and drug addict!  A bit of an idiot and not much going on between the ears.  A ladies man and can be a bit of a charmer but usually once they get to know him, they realize he’s a dopy annoying ‘stoner’.  He likes Tiffany because she has loads of money and game for a laugh. Comes along for the ride of his life! 

Timothy Carhart as the Sheriff 

By appearance he's the trustworthy sheriff in town with an evil, sinister side to him. 

Lorna Scott as Marge

Larger than life in personality, Marge is part of the crazy town folk of Lake Isabella. With a creepy undertone - you wouldn't want to be trapped in her trailer late at night! 

Paul Duke as Jones

   

Lives in a trailer park.  He’s a major ass, a bit of a joker, and on crack.  Drug dealer, government sponge, and still the life of the party.


Our Fabulous Crew 

Director - Scott Donovan 

Scott Donovan is a writer, director, actor based in Los Angeles. After moving to the west coast from New York, Scott acted on TV shows such as "E.R.", "Alias", "Angel", "Drive" and "Total Security", in addition to a number of independent films. He has acted and directed for numerous theatre companies, while he honed his filmmaking skills. He wrote and directed numerous shorts, leading up to his first feature film "Black Cobra" which was released by Lionsgate in May 2012. He is currently working on two upcoming feature films in addition to numerous writing projects. He’s looking forward to sinking his teeth into the horror genre with F***, Marry, Kill.



Cinematographer - John Orphan

We are very excited to have John Orphan as our Cinematographer.  John has worked on many wonderful films including ""Paper Heart" with Seth Rogen, "Life is Hot in Cracktown" with Desmond Harrington (also in Dexter),  "Adventures of Power" with Adrian Grenier, Jane Lynch and Michael McKean, and "Cleaner" with Samuel L. Jackson and Eva Mendes.


The table read with all the cast


Screen Shots from the shoot

  

   

   

   

 




Why shoot F***, Marry, Kill?

The concept for this film started with Rachel’s connection with Lake Isabella. Her husband is from this rural town 3 hours north of Los Angeles. She originally was introduced to it when she met his family for the first time.

On that very first visit she knew the setting would make a captivating location for a film and kept it in the back of her mind for a possible future project. When the three of us got together and decided to make a horror film, that’s when the idea of shooting it in Lake Isabella was born. From there we had a concept meeting to create the story to best serve the purpose of this location. Once we developed the idea around 3 sisters traveling through the Mojave Desert to their brother’s wedding, everything started to fall into place. 

We ultimately decided to change the name to F***, Marry, Kill. For those not familiar this game is wildly popular, especially with Howard Stern listeners. The general idea is that you are given 3 names of celebrities or people you all know and then you have to choose which one you would F***, which one you would marry, and which one you would kill. It made an interesting title for our film based on the fact that the characters are playing this game on their road trip and it also has a nice play on words for the events that start to happen to them once they reach the town.


What is this town 'Lake Isabella'?

Situated in the Mojave Desert, Lake Isabella used to be a thriving tourist town with a beautiful lake.  In the last 10 years tourism has been driven away due to the lake drying up.  

We thought the concept of this film being based around this lake would be perfect.

               

   

Upon visiting this very deserted community, we came across some amazing visual locations and interesting town folk.


How We'll Use The Money


We are half way there with our budget from getting this movie made.  With your help, WE CAN DO IT!  We really need our last bit of funding for Post-Production in getting this movie edited.  We need the footage edited and music added.  We also have some pick up shots to shoot so we will need to hire our super awesome crew for camera, lighting and sound equipment that will tie pieces together.  Marketing this film will get us out there and seen to the world along with festival circuit submissions and lastly Indiegogo fees. 

Risks & Challenges

This project was very challenging to film as we were filming on location up in the Mojave Desert.  The heat combined with wind and dust made it than much more challenging, also half of the movie is in the dark so lighting was extremely important. But what we came away with from our shoot was amazing professional footage.  We are very proud of the material we have, we now just need to get the finished product edited and out there.

Been on a tough budget is extremely hard and we really want to make this movie stand out and be a movie to remember!  But regardless of our risks and challenges, we are very positive and confident that we can do this and we won't stop until we get there!


Frequently Asked Questions


If you reach your goal, should I still contribute?

Absolutely! The more we have the bigger the scale of this production can be.  We also need to publicize as much as possible so the more help the better. 

When do you expect to release the film?

We are taking the film on the festival circuit so as soon as its been premiered, we will let you know.

When can I expect to receive my Perks?

We want to get them out to you as soon as possible which will be as soon as we have done the festival circuit.

I have/know a person/company that would love to get involved and help you.  How do I refer them? 

If you have someone interested in our project then please contact us through the campaign.

Can I give my contribution Perk as a gift? 

Yes, when we contact you to fulfill the Perk, just give us the address you want the items shipped or sent to, and we will happily do so.

Can I select more than one Perk?

Absolutely! More the merrier.
Select one of the Perks first, and then add up the total amount of all the Perks you'd like and enter that as the total amount you're going to pledge. After that is completed come back to this page and click the "Contact Me" button under the "Back this Project" button on the top right side of the page and let us know which combination of Perks you'd like. After we receive your message we'll send you a confirmation and you're all set! 

What can I do to see the movie or the progress? 

We will be keeping you updated through the social media sites.  You will be informed by email any information we have on premieres, release dates and festival screenings.


Other Ways You Can Help

We do understand that not everyone can contribute financially, but there is a different way you can help.  We would love you to make some noise and help us get the word out about our campaign.  This can be done by just telling your friends and family by sharing the Indiegogo share tool.

Thank you so much!

Janine, Rachel & Catherine
story_txt:
We are three actresses Janine Gateland, Catherine Eure and Rachel Ryling who are producing the short thriller F***, Marry, Kill.  Created and written by us, we can't wait to tell you all about it and take you on our journey in getting this awesome film made!What is the film about?

F***, Marry, Kill is a short thriller, directed by Scott Donovan.  The story follows three sisters traveling through the Mojave Desert on their way to their brothers wedding.




A sinister turn of events leads them to a twisted, maddening town where a psychotic, cult-like community kidnaps women and forces them to marry, procreate or be sacrificed.  These residents seem hell bent on making it their final destination.

Why back our film?
We have a wonderful script, concept, amazing locations, fabulous cast & crew, and now awesome footage.  Some of the cast include Timothy Carhart known for "Thelma and Louise", "Ghostbusters", "The Hunt for Red October"  and "Witness".  We are also pleased to say we have the lovely Lorna Scott known for "Wanted", "Little Britain USA", "The Guilt Trip", "Little Boy", "Sorded Lives" and HBO TV series "True Blood".
We are half way there to getting this funded and need a little of your help.


Who we are







Janine Gateland 
Janine is so pleased to
be finally creating her own work. She is the executive producer and
writer of F***, Marry, Kill and is also playing the leading role ‘Tiffany Forbes’.
British born and London drama school trained, Janine went on to appear in London's West End at The Soho Theater, The Criterion Theater and The Courtyard Theater in "Forget me Knot" and "Twelfth Night" at The Tabard Theater. She has worked on many successful films including "The Test"; which was taken to Cannes Film Festival. In addition, she shot a British national commercial for "Nintendo Wii" and a U.S national commercial for "Disney".  Currently in post-production for the horror "The Closing" and in pre-production for the leading role 'Sarah Adams' in romantic comedy "Let's Just Do It".

Rachel
Ryling
Rachel Ryling was born in
Nashville, Tennessee and is the daughter of a military officer.  Upon graduation she moved to Los Angeles and entered the Liberal Arts program at Pepperdine University to pursue her career as an actress. 
From there she has worked on various
independent films and recently attended Cannes Film festival due to her role 'Lucille' in the feature "Western Religion".  She has also been cast as 'Veronica Stampler' in the popular web series "The Adventures of Velvet Prozak".
She is so pleased to now be involved in this project which will solidify her status as a triple threat in the industry as she is credited
as a writer, producer, and actress on this film.

Catherine Eure
Catherine Eure is thrilled to be producing, writing and acting in
F***, Marry, Kill alongside Rachel Ryling and Janine Gateland.  Her love of the horror/thriller genre and her
desire to create a girl-powered production are married thanks to the journey of
this film.  
A North Carolina native,
Catherine grew up performing in musical theater and moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in film and TV.  She’s worked in  many independent feature
films and has studied acting for most of her life, including training at The Ivana Chubbuck Studio, Stella Adler and The Lee Strasberg Institute.  This
project brings her passions for all things creepy, creative control, feminism,
and filmmaking  together and she couldn’t
be more excited.



Claude Duhamel
Claude Duhamel, born in Montreal, Quebec, is a
Canadian film and television actor. He is known for his work on “Valentine", "Destination Vegas", "Dawn Rider" and “Western
Religion”.
He studied at the Montreal Actor Studio for 3 years doing mostly improv and theater.
Claude pursued his career in Vancouver where he compiled more than 50
Television and Film credits and made a name for himself playing eccentric and
dark characters through the next decade. Claude Duhamel continues to keep his
dream alive working as a successful actor. He is no stranger to intriguing
characters with diverse accents, capable transforming into a chameleon like
presence on screen.
He maintains residency in Los Angeles, Vancouver
and Montreal.

quickly started working both Off and On

story:
The arts have catalysed huge changes in people’s lives.  Have you heard of Daniel Barenboim, the conductor who brought Israeli’s and Palestinian’s together through a mutual love for Beethoven? Did you know that Lucy Walker's documentary Waste Land (2011), about the artist Vik Muniz's work with garbage collectors in Brazil not only spurred a conversation across the world about how waste could make art, but catalyzed profound changes in the lives of these people, enabling them to get better jobs and, in one case, sell their art for over $64,000?  Or have you heard about Hua Dan, an innovative non-profit in China, using theatre as a tool to empower migrant workers from the countryside to both benefit from and contribute to the huge changes in Chinese society?

The arts are also helping to propel the economy forward.  These days, the creative industries are one of the fastest-growing sectors of almost all world economies. From 2002 to 2011, the global creative economy more than doubled, reaching a record US$624 billion.  At the same time, developing economies averaged 12.1 per cent annual growth in the export of creative goods.  In the USA alone, the copyright industries account for 11% of GDP, which is significantly larger than the finance and insurance, construction, health and Federal Government sectors.

The Global Arts Impact Agenda is building a movement to enable government and business to unleash human potential through the arts.  Our vision is of a world where the arts and culture are habitually and by default utilised in government-led and corporate initiatives to build healthy, happy and prosperous communities, regardless of whether those initiatives are political, economic or social.

We have produced a series of reports that show evidence of governments and businesses successfully using the arts to make communities and organisations healthier, happier and more prosperous. We have found success stories across all sectors and subjects, from healthcare and education to sustainability and urbanisation and beyond.

With the first of these reports in the hands of governments and businesses, we can help public and private organisations understand exactly how the arts can help. The reports will also provide best practices to adapt and use in their own contexts.

The Big Picture

We will then launch a global movement to make the arts at the front and centre of public policy initiatives. The heart of this will be a ‘Charter for the Arts’ that we will develop based on the results of these initial reports.

The reports and the Charter will then form the bedrock of an annual 'Best Practices in the Arts' global index. The index will rate each country according to the strengths in provision for the arts, then identify gaps to be filled.

Our International Strategic Programmes team will then deliver 2 - 3 year projects to help countries meet the criteria established in our 'Charter for the Arts'. We are targetting 10 governments to be signed up to the Charter by 2025.

We are looking for an initial £5000 to support the editing of the reports, the infrastructure needed to establish GAIA as a legal entity, and build our initial partnerships.

Professor Nigel Osborne and Brian Eno leading music therapy workshops in Mostar, Bosnia, with Warchild. (1994-95) Photo credit: Keith Brame

Vik Muniz making art with waste, in Waste Land (2011) Film credit: Lucy Walker


What We Need and What You Get

For £5000 we can publish the first ‘Best Practices in the Arts’ report and establish ourselves as a legal entity.  As a founding donor, you will have the opportunity to be part of building our movement and being one of our first members.  We are offering a range of perks to our founding donors, including free downloads and printed copies of the 'Best Practices in the Arts' report, membership to our online community and opportunities to participate in our events.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will explore other fundraising avenues to finance our long-term goals.  We are determined!

We operate the Global Arts Impact Agenda on the basis of transparency according to the World Blu model of democratic organisation and are happy to furnish our donors with a breakdown of how the funds were used.

By the way, if you would like to donate a more significant amount to support our short and long-term goals, please contact donate@globalartsagenda.org to co-create your own perks!

Our team

Caroline Watson is our Executive Director, assisted by Fanny Ollivier, former Senior Programme Associate for Arts and Culture at the World Economic Forum, as Operations Manager, and Nigel Osborne is Chairman of the Board.  Richard Sobey is Director of International Strategic Initiatives.   Rakhi Birla is our Senior Associate working on business planning and fundraising.

   

         Caroline Watson - Executive Director        Fanny Ollivier - Operations                  

          
    Nigel Osborne - Chairman             Richard Sobey - International Strategic Initiatives

     

     Rakhi Birla - Senior Associate


The Impact

As artists and arts workers ourselves, we know that we need opportunities to amplify our voices and make the value of the arts more widely seen and felt.  Our commitment to you is that our work is real-world focused, grassroots-led and shaped and supported by those at the coal face of bringing arts to the world. 

The reports and the ‘best practices’ platform will give art workers practical tools to take to their donors and supporters to help them understand why their work is valuable, and will show the public and private sectors how the arts can be leveraged for the benefit of ALL. 

The Global Arts Impact Agenda founder, Caroline, has been widely recognised for the impact of her work with Hua Dan, having built and grown the organisation from an idea to one of the most respected arts organisations in China.  This is no mean feat in a country that has no precedent for using the arts for social change and, as someone who bootstrapped the organisation, Caroline knows first hand the challenges with running an organisation and the needs of artists like herself.  Such was her success, that Caroline was recognised as a Young Global Leader of the World Economic Forum.

We are building a movement that will benefit ALL humanity - and we want YOU to be a part of it!

Risks & Challenges

Like many organisations, one of our biggest risks is finding sufficient funds to achieve our objectives.  However, we are confident in what we are offering, committed to making this happen and we believe that this is what the world most needs right now.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don’t feel you can contribute to the campaign financially at this stage, there are loads of other ways in which you can help:

  • Share our campaign with others who you think can help.
  • Tweet, Facebook and promote our campaign through your social media networks
  • Consider asking one of your supporters if they can sponsor your membership
  • Help us to design a logo!
  • In-kind and pro bono support - air miles, event space, legal or accounting support

And we welcome any other creative idea! Feel free to contact us at donate@globalartsagenda.org.
story_txt:
The arts have catalysed huge changes in people’s lives.  Have you
heard of Daniel Barenboim, the conductor who brought Israeli’s and
Palestinian’s together through a mutual love for Beethoven? Did you know
that Lucy Walker's documentary Waste Land (2011), about the artist Vik
Muniz's work with garbage collectors in Brazil not only spurred a conversation
across the world about how waste could make art, but catalyzed profound changes
in the lives of these people, enabling them to get better jobs and, in one case,
sell their art for over $64,000?  Or have
you heard about Hua Dan, an innovative non-profit in China, using theatre as a
tool to empower migrant workers from the countryside to both benefit from and
contribute to the huge changes in Chinese society?
The arts are also helping to propel the economy
forward.  These days, the creative
industries are one of the fastest-growing sectors of almost all world
economies. From 2002 to 2011, the global creative economy more than doubled,
reaching a record US$624 billion.  At the
same time, developing economies averaged 12.1 per cent annual growth in the
export of creative goods.  In the USA alone, the copyright industries
account for 11% of GDP, which is significantly larger than the finance and
insurance, construction, health and Federal Government sectors.
The Global Arts Impact Agenda is
building a movement to enable government and business to unleash human
potential through the arts.  Our vision is of a world
where the arts and culture are habitually and by default utilised in
government-led and corporate initiatives to build healthy, happy and prosperous
communities, regardless of whether those initiatives are political, economic or
social.We
have produced a series of reports that show evidence of governments and
businesses successfully using the arts to make communities and organisations
healthier, happier and more prosperous. We have found success stories across
all sectors and subjects, from healthcare and education to sustainability and
urbanisation and beyond.
With
the first of these reports in the hands of governments and businesses, we can
help public and private organisations understand exactly how the arts can help.
The reports will also provide best practices to adapt and use in their own
contexts.
The
Big Picture
We
will then launch a global movement to make the arts at the front and centre of
public policy initiatives. The heart of this will be a ‘Charter for the Arts’
that we will develop based on the results of these initial reports.
The
reports and the Charter will then form the bedrock of an annual 'Best Practices
in the Arts' global index. The index will rate each country according to the
strengths in provision for the arts, then identify gaps to be filled.
Our
International Strategic Programmes team will then deliver 2 - 3 year projects
to help countries meet the criteria established in our 'Charter for the Arts'.
We are targetting 10 governments to be signed up to the Charter by 2025.We are looking for an initial £5000 to support the editing of the reports, the infrastructure needed to establish GAIA as a legal entity, and build our initial partnerships.


Professor
Nigel Osborne and Brian Eno leading music therapy workshops in Mostar, Bosnia,
with Warchild. (1994-95) Photo credit: Keith Brame


Vik Muniz making art with waste, in Waste Land (2011) Film credit: Lucy Walker

story:
Glen Casey was born and raised amid a world of drugs and violence. But with the help of counselors, mentors, teachers — and most of all, a mother who never quit on him — he’s successfully completed his sophomore year at the University of Pennsylvania. 

“Glen’s Village” immerses viewers in Glen's West Philadelphia neighborhood and the nearby Penn campus in University City. Although just a few blocks apart, the two communities might as well be separated by oceans. Glen's journey from 9th grade troublemaker dealing crack cocaine on the streets to attending an Ivy League institution is filled with bumps, bruises and redemption.

"A powerful and moving story about one teenager overcoming the odds — and a call to action for more resources for inner city schools."  -Pamela Hogan, Filmmaker

Journalists Dorian Geiger and Paul Jablow directed and produced this powerful documentary for non-profit publication The Philadelphia Public School Notebook, which probes the impact of trauma on children, and what a difference it can make when a young person gets the supports they need to grow.

We need your help to bring "Glen's Village" to a wide audience – particularly to education professionals and advocates who work with children impacted by trauma. The film's message needs to be heard: that there are many Glens out there whose behavior may be misunderstood and who aren't getting the supports they need. 

"You need to carve 30 minutes out of your day and watch the mini-documentary 'Glen’s Village.'" 

-Mike Lyons, Writer and Co-Owner | West Philly Local

Our goal is to create "Glen's Village" packages containing the film, a discussion guide and poster that we can mail out to principals, high school guidance counselors and other child advocates who want to screen the film. 

"This film needs to be shown in every inner city school across the country." -Rich Neal, Behavioral Specialist | NorthEast Treatment Centers

We also hope to enter the film in multiple film festivals to raise its profile as a way to spark discussions about childhood trauma. The film was just accepted into Atlanta's Peachtree Village International Film Festival and Santa Fe's AMFM Fest – we want to build on that success! 

We are seeking $6,000 to fund our film promotion project. Our proposed budget includes:

$3,000 - to produce and distribute "Glen's Village" kits to schools and nonprofits

$2,000 - to enter and participate in film festivals

$1,000 - to produce materials to promote "Glen's Village" as a resource for understanding childhood trauma

The Philadelphia Public School Notebook (thenotebook.org) is an independent, reader-supported nonprofit news organization that covers the Philadelphia public schools. The Notebook serves as an information source and voice for parents, students, teachers, and other members of the community who are working for quality and equality in Philadelphia's public schools. 

"'Glen's Village' is a powerful story that illuminates how much agency students like Glen have, waiting to be supported... and how much work we have to do as a society to give them the opportunities they deserve." 

- AJ Schiera, Public School Teacher and Researcher | Consortium for Policy Research and Education, University of Pennsylvania

story:
Greetings Friends! My name is Michael Joel Denson and I am a mixed media artist working in Phoenix, Arizona. I have recently been given this unique opportunity to travel to India and be a part of an international artist residency with Reflection Art Gallery in New Delhi. This residency will facilitate meaningful cultural engagement and address important, current social issues through the arts. The theme for this 18 day residency is Human Dignity: The Many Faces of Abundance. Joined with  6 international and 6 Indian artists, we will be exploring the idea of  "abundance" in the light of middle-class aspirations and the lives of scavenger families working on one of Delhi's "Garbage Mountains".

Why is this Important?

This is an amazing opportunity to use art as tool for social justice and awareness; to break down international borders and spark cross-cultural dialogue. I believe that the foundation of this residency is a breeding ground for powerful art. Art that has the power to change. It is my desire to use these gifts that God has given me to aid in the Kingdom work that is being done in New Delhi.

My passion as an artist comes from the need to explore the human condition. I love to dig deep into the human soul and bring to light our struggles, our concerns, our feelings, or just our ideas. Starting here I can tell stories that address these ideas. As an artist it is my desire that viewer would interact and dialogue with my work. I hope that it is here that God can speak and connect with those that are receptive.

I am really inspired by the concept of human dignity and what that looks like for different cultures. With this residency I am looking to use my art medium to lift up the people of New Delhi. I want to represent them and their struggles in a very real way, but I also want them to be seen as God sees them.

View my portfolio at www.michaeljoeldenson.com 


What We Need & What You Get

As my wife, Charith Denson, who is also and artist, will be joining me on the trip and serving as a documentary photographer. Our costs cover us both.

  • We need to raise $5,500                                                                                               $3000 covers round-trip airfare for two                                                                      $1600 covers residency fees, room and board for two                                               $500 in estimated art supplies and materials                                                             $400 we would like to contribute and at least this amount to the residency program to support the Art for Change Foundation in New Delhi in their mission to continue programs such as this and workshops that uplift the marginalized.
  • 100% of the funds will cover the entire trip for both of us
  • In gratitude of your participation and support I have created a set of original artwork. These are unique to this campaign and are for you to enjoy and be inspired by (see descriptions in perks). In addition, you are also supporting the Reflection Gallery in its efforts to bring hope and restoration to the people of New Delhi.

Meet Me in New Delhi

Acrylic and ink on canvas


Bring Life 

Acrylic and ink on canvas


Bring Hope

Acrylic and ink on canvas



  • If we happen to raise more than our goal of $5,500 we will be producing reproductions of the art pieces created during the residency as well as photo books documenting the trip. These will be given to our the highest donors. Additional funds will be donated to the Arts for Change Foundation. 


Risks & Challenges

Time. This residency is coming up fast and we will need to move forward with our plans ASAP.

I also realize that many people think that art may not be important or is not something that can truly "make a difference". Pushing through this view is challenging for artists but I intend to show, to the best of my ability, how successful this process can be.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute financially that's okay! You can still make some noise. Help us by getting the word out by sharing our link on your social media sites or by using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • And the best way of course, is PRAY!
